title: This Revolutionary Moment in Space Exploration | Chris Hadfield | TED
description:
What does it feel like to see Earth from outer space and imagine humanity's next steps? Astronaut Chris Hadfield, who has flown two Space Shuttle missions and served as commander of the International Space Station, explores the recent leaps in space exploration. From the thrills and risks of commercial space travel to collaborating as a species to shape the future, Hadfield reflects on what inspires innovation and our dreams of visiting the stars. (This conversation, hosted by TED's Whitney Pennington Rodgers, was part of an exclusive TED Membership event. TED Membership is the best way to support and engage with the big ideas you love from TED. To learn more, visit ted.com/membership.) (Recorded at TED Membership on October 28, 2025)

title: Turns out your brain likes leg day, too #TEDTalks
description: What's the most transformative thing that you can do for your brain today? Exercise! says neuroscientist Wendy Suzuki. Get inspired to go to the gym as Suzuki discusses the science of how working out boosts your mood and memory -- and protects your brain against neurodegenerative diseases like Alzheimer's.

title: The Army of Autonomous Robots Restoring Nature | Tom Chi | TED
description:
Impact investor Tom Chi challenges a dangerous assumption: that economic growth and ecological health are opposing forces. He reveals how advances in AI and robotics are enabling a radical shift towards innovation as a force for restoration. Imagine mines that extract less, farms that regenerate soil and fleets of robots that can plant 100,000 mangroves in a single day. What if the same technologies that power our economy could actively repair the planet at the same time? (Recorded at TED Countdown and Bezos Earth Fund on September 24, 2025)

Countdown is TED's global initiative to accelerate solutions to the climate crisis. The goal: to build a better future by cutting greenhouse gas emissions in half by 2030, in the race to a zero-carbon world. Get involved at https://countdown.ted.com

description:

Impact entrepreneur Mercedes Bidart shows how AI is letting informal entrepreneurs in Latin America transform "invisible data" on their phones into a financial identity, helping them get credit and grow on their own terms. title: Let's Learn English! Topic: Home Remedies! üçØüßñüçµ (Lesson Only)
description:
In this English lesson, you‚Äôll learn useful vocabulary and common phrases for talking about simple home remedies for everyday health problems. We‚Äôll look at clear, real-life examples such as sipping tea to soothe a sore throat, using warm or cold compresses for headaches and sore muscles, and applying aloe vera to calm sunburn or irritated skin.

You‚Äôll also pick up natural expressions English speakers use when describing minor illnesses, taking care of themselves at home, and dealing with small aches and discomforts that usually don‚Äôt need a visit to the doctor.

By the end of the lesson, you‚Äôll feel confident talking about basic home treatments and self-care in natural, everyday English conversations.

‚åõ Remember:  Always watch the video three times.  Twice today with the English subtitles on, and once tomorrow with the English subtitles off.  This will reinforce the English you have learned!

title: Will AI Make Humans Useless? | Akram Awad | TED
description:
"As jobs disappear, so will identity," says AI futurist Akram Awad, outlining the three types of people that will emerge as AI continues to replace the workforce. He introduces the blueprint for a society built not on wealth and job titles but on purpose and societal contributions, offering a framework to reimagine who you are ‚Äî and a way for society to avoid a collective identity crisis. (Recorded at TED@BCG on October 23, 2025)

title: English Drinking Verbs: Sip, Chug, Gulp & More!
description:
New Year's Eve is just about here! The holidays are a great time to review drinking vocabulary in English.

In this short lesson for English language learners, you‚Äôll learn common verbs and nouns related to drinking, including the difference between:
‚Ä¢ sip
‚Ä¢ gulp
‚Ä¢ chug
‚Ä¢ slurp
You‚Äôll also hear natural examples and some etiquette tips. This everyday vocabulary is useful year-round, but especially helpful for social events, parties, and celebrations like New Year‚Äôs Eve. Understanding these verbs will help you follow conversations more easily and choose your words with confidence.

Raise a glass, make a toast, and enjoy learning English ‚Äî one sip at a time!

title: What if we could have AI and *not* harm the planet? #TEDTalks
description: Artificial intelligence is changing everything ‚Äî but at what cost? AI sustainability expert Sasha Luccioni exposes how tech companies' massive data centers are burning through energy and wrecking the planet. She introduces a powerful alternative: small but mighty AI models that could flip the script and make the technology smarter, fairer and sustainable.

title: How to Stop AI from Killing Your Critical Thinking | Advait Sarkar | TED
description:
Chatbots might help you get work done faster ‚Äî but at what cost? When we outsource our reasoning to artificial intelligence, we reduce ourselves to "middle managers for our own thoughts," says AI and design researcher Advait Sarkar. He examines the cognitive trade-offs of using AI at work and introduces a different kind of tool: one that encourages critical thinking, nudges reflection and actually helps you get smarter. (Recorded at TEDAI Vienna on September 26, 2025)

title: How the Fridge Changed Food | Nicola Twilley | TED
description:
What if your kitchen fridge is just the tip of an iceberg that's reshaping the world? Food storyteller Nicola Twilley reveals how the massive ‚Äúartificial Arctic‚Äù we built to keep our food fresh is simultaneously melting the real one. She shows why we're at a critical moment to rethink our relationship with the cold chain and refrigeration ‚Äî and explores the emerging technologies that could keep food fresh without putting the planet on thin ice. (Recorded at TED Countdown Summit 2025 on June 17, 2025)

title: Family bonding, but make it co-op mode #TEDTalks
description: Parenting an eye-rolling teenager glued to a gaming system is not a simple feat, but what if you could turn screen time into an opportunity for connection? Hannah Boquet shares how she decided to play video games with her kids and discovered the power of esports to foster trust, communication and essential life skills. Dive deeper into how you can strengthen family bonds, support your child‚Äôs development ‚Äî and maybe even be considered ‚Äúcool‚Äù by your kid.

title: Why Are People Starting to Sound Like ChatGPT? | Adam Aleksic | TED
description:
Algorithms and AI don't just show us reality ‚Äî they warp it in ways that benefit platforms built to exploit people for profit, says etymologist Adam Aleksic. From ChatGPT influencing our word choices to Spotify turning a data cluster into a new musical genre, he reveals how new technology subconsciously shapes our language, trends and sense of identity. "These aren't neutral tools," he says, encouraging us to constantly ask ourselves: How am I being influenced? (Recorded at TEDNext 2025 on November 11, 2025)

title: Let's Learn English! Topic: Home Remedies! üçØüßñüçµ
description:
In this English lesson I'll help you learn vocabulary and everyday phrases for talking about home remedies for minor ailments. We‚Äôll use simple, real life examples like drinking tea for a sore throat, applying a cold or warm compress for headaches and muscle pain, and using aloe vera for sunburn or skin irritation.

You‚Äôll also learn common expressions English speakers use when talking about feeling unwell, self-care at home, and small health problems that don‚Äôt require a doctor.

By the end of the lesson, you‚Äôll be able to describe simple home remedies people use to feel better in everyday English conversations.

title: Which toy did you love as a kid? #TEDTalks
description: What was your favorite toy when you were a kid? Your answer might reveal more about you than you expect, says toy historian Chris Byrne. From Matchbox cars and Barbie to Rubik's Cube and Squishmallows, he explores how playthings reflect cultural values and influence who you become as an adult.

title: An Art Movement Built on Ancestral Wisdom | Jackie Lebo | TED
description:
"How are the children? How are the cattle? Is it raining?" Filmmaker Jackie Lebo discovered the meaning of this traditional greeting when she and nine other artists explored Turkana, an isolated part of Kenya where the discovery of oil has disrupted pastoral life. Through film, photography and music, she and musicians Elizabeth Korikel and Eddie Grey share the deep cultural roots of art ‚Äî and highlight the true connectedness of humanity. (Recorded at TED2025 on April 9, 2025)

title: Fix your wandering agents via spec-driven development
description:
If your coding agent is constantly going on weird side quests, try using spec-driven development. With spec-driven development, you focus on giving agents clear goals, constraints, and a clear definition of ‚Äúdone‚Äù. Learn the three steps needed to create a blueprint for spec-driven development for agents. 

Subscribe to Google for Developers ‚Üí https://goo.gle/developers 

Speaker: Jasmyne Roberts

title: Struggling communities need bold new ways to grow wealth #TEDTalks
description: Struggling communities don‚Äôt need handouts ‚Äî they need bold new ways to root wealth. Meet Molly Hemstreet ‚Äî a TED Fellow, Southern Appalachia native and cofounder of worker support network the Industrial Commons ‚Äî who‚Äôs flipping the script on generational poverty by turning textile waste into $9-per-pound yarn and factory workers into business owners. Discover how her long-haul approach is rebuilding rural economies stitch by stitch, proving that opportunity grows when we stop extracting and start empowering.

title: 4 Hard Truths About Capitalism and Climate | Steve Howard | TED
description:
For decades, investor and business leader Steve Howard watched companies pour money and effort into sustainability initiatives ... and still fall short. The problem isn‚Äôt a lack of will, he says; it‚Äôs that capitalism and climate have been wired to work against each other. He shares four realities that explain why even well-intentioned businesses fail at climate action ‚Äî as well as a plan to flip the system, making green innovation so powerful the market can‚Äôt resist it.(Recorded at TED Countdown Summit 2025 on June 17, 2025)

title: Let's Learn English! Topic: Adjectives for Work! üë©üèΩ‚Äçüè≠üè≠üõ†Ô∏è (Lesson Only)
description:
In this English lesson, you‚Äôll learn useful work adjectives that English speakers commonly use to talk about jobs, workplaces, systems, and productivity. These words are helpful when discussing offices, factories, teamwork, management styles, and everyday work tasks.

You‚Äôll study vocabulary such as efficient, wasteful, productive, unproductive, streamlined, chaotic, well run, poorly run, fast paced, time saving, time consuming, inefficient, and more practical adjectives used in real work situations.

By the end of the lesson, you‚Äôll be able to describe how work gets done, explain whether a workplace is organized or chaotic, and talk clearly about performance and productivity. This practical English lesson will help you sound more natural and confident when speaking about work.

‚åõ Remember:  Always watch the video three times.  Twice today with the English subtitles on, and once tomorrow with the English subtitles off.  This will reinforce the English you have learned!

title: Do I Need a Perfect Accent to Be Successful?
description:
Do I need a perfect accent to be successful? Let's talk about mindset.

I‚Äôm an English teacher, but I‚Äôm also a language learner. In this short, I share my honest experience learning Spanish as an adult (over 50). I'm not trying to learn as fast as possible, and I don‚Äôt aim for a "perfect" accent but rather accurate pronunciation. I focus on achieving successful communication, understanding others, and being understood ‚Äî while keeping my sense of identity.

Aim to know more than you did yesterday. And keep going!

This message is for English learners (and all language learners) who experience pressure to sound exactly like a native. No one has "perfect" pronunciation. We all have some kind of accent. An accent does not prevent you from communicating well. And progress doesn‚Äôt have to be fast to be meaningful. You can learn a language, enjoy the process, and succeed...even with an accent.

Focus on having clear speech and continue to master enough grammar and vocabulary to express yourself.

Watch more videos on building a healthy learner mindset.

You‚Äôll learn vocabulary such as: efficient, wasteful, productive, unproductive, streamlined, chaotic, well run, poorly run, fast paced, time saving and time consuming and many more.

By the end of this lesson you‚Äôll be able to clearly describe how work is done whether a workplace is organized or chaotic and how people and systems perform at work. This practical English lesson will help you sound more confident and natural when talking about work and productivity.

title: Introducing FunctionGemma
description:
Meet FunctionGemma, a specialized version of the Gemma 3 270M model, fine-tuned specifically for function calling and tool use and designed to be fine-tuned further.

In this video, Kat Black (Product Manager, Google DeepMind) and Ravin Kumar (Research Scientist, Google DeepMind) introduce how this lightweight model enables developers to build fast, private, and cost-effective applications that translate natural language into executable API actions. Despite its small size (only 270 million parameters), FunctionGemma is designed to run efficiently on-device, making it perfect for mobile hardware, embedded systems, and edge computing.

We also showcase two demos running on Google AI Edge: Mobile Actions that controls device features (like the flashlight and calendar) via voice, and an interactive farming game driven entirely by natural language commands.

Resources:
Announcing FunctionGemma, a specialized version of our Gemma 3 270M model that‚Äôs fine-tuned for function calling ‚Üí https://goo.gle/44ViZ6n  
Train your own specialized agent with our Colab notebook ‚Üí https://goo.gle/4p7SqCb
Run your specialized Mobile Actions model in Google AI Edge Gallery ‚Üí https://goo.gle/49jPJIK

Subscribe to Google for Developers ‚Üí https://goo.gle/developers 

Speakers: Kat Black, Ravin Kumar

title: Keras Recommenders: reliable, state-of-the-art recommendations for ranking and retrieval
description:
Building a recommendation system that is high-quality, high-performance, and hallucination-free can be a challenge. In this video, Yufeng Guo introduces Keras Recommenders (KerasRS), a library designed to help developers build reliable ranking and retrieval models with ease.

We‚Äôll walk through a complete code example using the MovieLens dataset to build a Sequential Retrieval model. Using a Gated Recurrent Unit (GRU) to analyze a user's watch history, we will predict exactly which movie they are likely to watch next.

Because KerasRS is built on Keras 3, this workflow is compatible with your choice of backend: TensorFlow, JAX, or PyTorch.

In this video, you will learn:
- What Keras Recommenders is and why it‚Äôs useful
- How to prepare sequential data (using the "snake" method) for training
- How to build a two-tower architecture with a query tower (GRU) and candidate tower
- How to use the BruteForceRetrieval layer for accurate predictions

Resources:
Build and train a recommender system in 10 minutes using Keras and JAX  ‚Üí https://goo.gle/44VVj1J   
Keras Recommenders Documentation ‚Üí https://goo.gle/495DAG9 
Check out the Code Example ‚Üí https://goo.gle/3KBM140 

Chapters: 
0:00 - Introduction: LLMs vs. Keras Recommenders 
0:40 - What is KerasRS? 
2:09 - Installation & Setup 
3:04 - Sequential Retrieval & GRU Explained 
4:30 - Preparing the MovieLens Dataset 
6:35 - Data Batching & Structure 
7:17 - Building the Two-Tower Model

8:28 - Conclusion & Next Steps

title: How to Talk Truthfully About Black History | Clint Smith | How to Be a Better Human | TED
description:
How do you grapple with national history, legacy, and the stories you tell yourself? Clint Smith is the author of the narrative nonfiction, How the Word is Passed, and the poetry collection, Above Ground. Clint joins Chris to talk about the cognitive dissonances that shaped American history. From understanding the complexities of Thomas Jefferson, who wrote ‚Äúall men are created equal‚Äù while enslaving over 600 people ‚Äì to reflecting on growing up in New Orleans ‚Äì a major site for domestic slave trades, Clint urges you to examine historical contradictions. He also discusses his love for poetry and why it‚Äôs crucial to teach joyous moments in Black history too. So students won‚Äôt see slavery and Jim Crow as the totality of the black historical experience but can envision themselves of possibilities beyond subjugation.

title: How to See (and Stop) Deforestation from Space | Tasso Azevedo | TED
description:
Nearly 20 trees are cut down every second in the Amazon rainforest, as authorities struggle to monitor millions of acres and stop illegal clear-cutting. But land reformer Tasso Azevedo and his team at MapBiomas have changed the game, transforming satellite imagery into precise, real-time maps that make every clear-cut visible ‚Äî and every actor accountable. Learn how they're helping slash deforestation in the Amazon, proving that transparency is a forest's strongest defense. (This ambitious idea is part of The Audacious Project, TED‚Äôs initiative to inspire and fund global change.) (Recorded at TED Countdown Summit 2025 on June 18, 2025)

title: Learning English? Get A Head Start This Month!
description:
Preply is a great way to find an English conversation partner. Find the perfect tutor to help you make real progress on your English learning journey! Use this link: https://preply.sjv.io/3J55Ln to get 50% off your first lesson or use code BOB50 at checkout. In my experience Preply is a great way to take your language learning to the next level!

In this English lesson I'll help you learn everyday phrases about timing, opportunity, and advantage. These are expressions English speakers use when talking about starting early, waiting too long, getting ahead, or falling behind in real life.

In this English class you‚Äôll learn clear meanings and real examples for phrases like to beat the rush, to miss the boat, the early bird gets the worm, too little too late, to beat the crowd, to be late to the party, first come first served, you snooze you lose, to be ahead of the game, to drag your feet, to be a step ahead, to be two steps behind, to get a head start, to play catch-up, to get started right away, to procrastinate, to have an edge, and to be at a disadvantage. These phrases are extremely common in work, school, travel, and everyday English conversations.

By the end of this lesson, you‚Äôll be able to talk confidently about decisions, timing, preparation, and results using natural English expressions. You‚Äôll sound clearer, more fluent, and more confident when describing real-life situations where timing really matters.

Thanks for watching, and enjoy this practical English lesson!

title: Follow My Model! The Secret to Clear, Confident English through Oral Reading
description:
Do you want to speak English more clearly and confidently? In this pronunciation and fluency lesson, I guide you through a powerful technique: oral reading.

In this long-form lesson for intermediate and advanced English learners, you‚Äôll read a meaningful text with me four different ways:
1Ô∏è‚É£ Listen only
2Ô∏è‚É£ Listen and repeat
3Ô∏è‚É£ Read along slowly
4Ô∏è‚É£ Read along at a natural pace

By following my model, you‚Äôll practice:
‚Ä¢ Clear pronunciation and word stress
‚Ä¢ Natural rhythm, pausing, and intonation
‚Ä¢ Connected speech (linking)
‚Ä¢ High-frequency vocabulary from the General Service List (GSL)
‚Ä¢ Grammar and collocations (natural word combinations) in context

Oral reading is an effective way to build speaking confidence while reinforcing listening, vocabulary, and overall fluency. Stay until the end for a short vocabulary quiz to check your understanding.

Index:
0:00 Intro
0:35 Reading 1
1:40 Study tips
2:24 Reading 2
5:02 Reading 3
6:44 Reading 4
7:58 Vocabulary quiz

title: Could this be a solution for humans in a world with more AI? #TEDTalks
description: Several crises are set to define the next century -- but journalist Aaron Bastani believes we have the technological ability to meet our biggest challenges and create unprecedented levels of prosperity for all. He shows how we could get there by ditching capitalism as the world's economic operating system and adopting "universal basic services," where governments would freely provide life essentials like housing, health care, education and transport.

title: Could We Detect Breast Cancer with a Fingerprint? | Simona Francese | TED
description:
Breast cancer is the most common cancer among women globally. And yet, many people pass up opportunities to get screened for the disease, often because of the invasive and sometimes painful process of mammograms. Chemist and professor Simona Francese presents a potentially groundbreaking alternative that could transform how and when we identify this deadly disease. (Recorded at TEDxManchester on March 1, 2025)

description:
In this English lesson, you‚Äôll learn common phrases that English speakers use to talk about everyday annoying situations. These are the little problems that can mess up your schedule, slow things down, or quietly push your patience to its limit. Learning these expressions will help you explain real-life frustrations in a clear, natural way.

In this class, we‚Äôll cover phrases like: locked out, running late for work, stuck in traffic, and oversleeping. You‚Äôll also learn how to talk about things such as a power outage, missing the bus, spilling coffee, losing your keys, a dead phone battery, forgetting your wallet, and other small but irritating moments.

By the end of the lesson, you‚Äôll be ready to describe life‚Äôs everyday annoyances more confidently and sound more natural in English conversations. I hope you enjoy this useful English lesson focused on common frustrating situations.

description:

title: Who‚Äôs Who at the North Pole? A Fun Christmas English Lesson
description:
Who all lives at the North Pole? In this holiday-themed English lesson, you‚Äôll learn the key characters that appear in American Christmas traditions.

In the U.S., children believe that Santa Claus lives at the North Pole, checking his list to see who‚Äôs naughty or nice before delivering presents around the world on Christmas Eve.

You‚Äôll learn:
üéÑ Santa‚Äôs different names in English (St. Nick, Kris Kringle, Father Christmas)
üéÑ Who helps Santa at the North Pole (Mrs. Claus and hardworking elves)
üéÑ The names of Santa‚Äôs famous reindeer team
üéÑ Why Rudolph leads the team of reindeer

This is a fun and friendly cultural lesson to help English learners understand American holiday references and build vocabulary at the same time. Perfect for intermediate learners who want to enjoy the season and learn something new!

title: Don't Mix These Up! 7 "Mind" Expressions You Should Know
description:
Confused by English expressions with ‚Äúmind‚Äù? This quick B2 vocabulary lesson will help you understand the differences between phrases like ‚Äúon your mind,‚Äù ‚Äúin mind,‚Äù ‚Äúout of your mind,‚Äù ‚Äúof the same mind,‚Äù and more.

Because these expressions use different prepositions, they can sound similar but have very different meanings.

In this short quiz-style lesson, you‚Äôll test your understanding and learn clear examples so you can start using these expressions naturally in conversations.

You‚Äôll learn:
‚Äì What ‚ÄúWhat do you have in mind?‚Äù really means
‚Äì When to ask ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs on your mind?‚Äù
‚Äì Why ‚ÄúAre you out of your mind?‚Äù sounds strong
‚Äì What it means when two people are "of the same mind"
‚Äì How to use ‚Äúin your right mind‚Äù
‚Äì The difference between ‚Äúkeep it in mind‚Äù and ‚Äúat the back of your mind‚Äù

Ideal for high intermediate and advanced English learners who want to boost vocabulary and feel more confident in conversation.

title: 5 linkers to make your conversation flow!
description:
Here are 5 linkers that you can add to your conversation to make it flow better and sound more fluent! 

1) To be honest ‚Äì I‚Äôm going to give my opinion (even if it‚Äôs insulting!)
2) Actually ‚Äì to correct information or say something surprising
3) Mind you ‚Äì I‚Äôve just thought of something that contrasts what I was saying
4) By the way ‚Äì I‚Äôm going to introduce a new topic I‚Äôve just remembered
5) Anyway ‚Äì I‚Äôm going to finish the conversation or change topic now

Add them to your conversations to help them flow! Which one is your favourite?

title: A2A and MCP explained: with ADK
description:
This video demystifies Agent-to-Agent (A2A) communication Protocol and the Model Context Protocol (MCP), two key open standards for creating sophisticated AI agents that can work together. We'll show you how to use the Agent Development Kit (ADK) to create specialized agents that can communicate, delegate tasks, and collaborate securely and efficiently to solve complex problems. Follow along with our practical guide to implement A2A and MCP in your own ADK projects.

title: Google Cloud & NVIDIA Experts Explain DRA: The New Way to Request GPUs in Kubernetes
description:

This is a must-watch for any developer or platform admin working with specialized hardware in Kubernetes.

title: What is TRUE? What is REAL? What's the difference between TRUTH & FALSEHOOD? - An English Lesson
description:
An English lesson explaining what is 'true' and what is 'fake'. Here is a question many people are asking right now. What is real? By this we are questioning the world around us. The things we see in our daily lives that may not be what they seem. Something that appears real or true may in fact be false or fake. This question can be stated in many different ways. You are asking what is genuine and true. You are wondering what to believe. Is it real? Is it true?

(About Mr Duncan)
Mr Duncan has been teaching English for free on YouTube for over 19 years. Have fun learning English as a second language. Language Captions are available.

title: A Casual English Lesson - Wednesdays with Bob #243
description:
Well, hello and welcome to Wednesdays with Bob. Remember, even though this isn't a traditional English lesson, it can be used as one. There are word for word English subtitles if you need to turn them on, and a complete English transcript in the description below.

So you might be wondering what's going on. Number one, it's not Wednesday today, it's Tuesday, as you watch this probably. And number, two, you might be thinking, I thought these videos, these Wednesdays with Bobs, were for members only. Well, this week is really, really busy for me and I didn't really have time to make an English lesson. And I didn't really have time to also make a Wednesdays with Bob. So I thought I would kill two birds with one stone.

In English, when you kill two birds with one stone, it means you get one thing done. You get two things done at the same time. Am I explaining that properly? It means that as I make this Wednesdays with Bob, I'm also going to put it out as my Tuesday video this week. So all of you who, who are members, thank you for supporting the channel. All of you who aren't members. This is one of, the things. This video is one of the things that members get, almost every Wednesday, actually I think 46 or 47 times out of the year, I do a Wednesdays with Bob video.

And what do I talk about in a Wednesdays with Bob video? Well, sometimes I just talk about the weather. I talk about how we have a little bit of snow here on the farm. I might talk about how it's really cold out here today. It's actually minus eight right now. I should probably be wearing, probably be wearing a winter hat. I also talk about my life and things that are going on.

One of the reasons why I'm busy is I need to go to work tonight. I have to go to work tonight to be recognized for working at the school for 25 years. I don't know if it's just going to be a little presentation. I don't know if I'm going to get a gift. But, I have to go to work, tonight.

And, last Friday night I actually had to chaperone a school dance. When you chaperone something as a teacher or as an adult, you are, responsible for, the behavior of the students who are at that event. So there was a school dance. I chaperoned it late Friday night. I still don't feel like I've fully recovered from that. I still feel pretty tired.

And then I have to go back to work tonight. But, it is, I guess me and a few other teachers are being recognized, for our years of service.

You might be wondering, do I ever talk about the chickens? Well, sometimes I do. The chickens actually at some point need to go into the barn. It's not too cold out here for them. They are protected from the wind. But I think this weekend we'll be moving them into the barn and they'll have a much more enjoyable place to be.

I'm trying to find Jen, but she's running away from me. She's, she's trying. I tried to hide from you, you're trying to hide from me. I'm killing two birds with one stone. I'm doing a Wednesdays with Bob, but then I'm going to release it Tuesday to everybody. So then I don't have to worry about, getting that done. I was just explaining how busy I am. Oh, and there's Walter. So, do you have anything to say to my wonderful audience? It's cold. It is cold. I wasn't ready for this. Yes, it's definitely colder than we expected.

Where am I at here? Oh, I've already talked for too long. I better wrap this up. So I'll walk away now. Anyways, this is what Wednesdays with Bob is. It's me rambling and there actually is some English to learn. If you want to learn a bit of English with this video. I've probably talked too long to include the whole transcript in the description at this point. So I will.

Are you racing me? So, so I'll probably put a link to the full transcript in the description below and you can use it as you see fit.

By the way, here's how you could use a video like this to learn English. You could read the transcript and then watch the video. You could watch the video with the subtitles on, then read the transcript and then watch the video again with the subtitles off. You can add a lot of variation. You can do this with other English speaking YouTube channels as well. And it just helps you, the repetition helps you to remember.

Anyways, thanks to all my members for being members and thanks to all the rest of you for watching my English lessons so faithfully every week. It has really helped me, to just have a lot of fun and enjoyment and to earn a bit of a living doing YouTube. So it's been fun and it's still fun. I'm not quitting or anything like that.

So anyways, have a good day. I'll see you hopefully, next week with an actual English lesson. But I'll for sure see you this Friday with a live English lesson. Bye.

--
‚úÖ If you would like to become a member of my channel here is the link: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCZJJTxA36ZPNTJ1WFIByaeA/join

title: Big Ben has nothing on the big ideas we saw in London. 1 more stop to go! #TEDTalks
How Climate Shocks Could Break the Economy | Edmond Rhys Jones | TED
description:
Climate change isn't just reshaping our planet ‚Äî it's also shaking the very foundations of the economy, says sustainability expert Edmond Rhys Jones. He explores the massive gap between what science tells us about the climate crisis and how the economy measures its impact, advocating for economists to borrow tools from science (like simulations and digital twins) to prepare for the turbulence ahead. title: How to Pronounce Tricky English Consonant Sounds
description:
Improve your English pronunciation with this 23-minute lesson focused on tricky consonant sounds. In this accent reduction session, I work with Nitish, my advanced learner from India, as we practice voiced and unvoiced consonants in common names and original tongue twisters.

We also take a deep dive into the /w/ sound and apply it to question words. You‚Äôll hear natural falling intonation in WH- questions and learn how rhythm and pitch affect clarity and confidence when you speak.

This lesson is ideal for intermediate and advanced learners who want to sound more natural, build stronger speaking habits, and communicate clearly in real conversations.

üü¶ What you‚Äôll practice:
‚Äì Voiced vs. unvoiced consonants: /p, b, f, v, s, z,  É,  í, t É, d í, w/
‚Äì Challenging words and names 
‚Äì Original tongue twisters
‚Äì /w/ in question words
‚Äì Falling intonation in WH- questions

If you want to strengthen your accent and speak with confidence, this session is for you!
üëâ Watch, repeat, and practice along.

title: Why are these two values different even though both seem to refer to nums? Go!
description:
Time for a winter dev challenge! In C, when you have an array and take its address, something interesting happens with sizeof. The array itself and a pointer to the array are fundamentally different types, and this code demonstrates exactly why that matters. Can you explain what's happening here? This is a subtle but important distinction in C programming that affects how you pass arrays to functions and understand memory layout. Share your explanation in the comments!

title: Economist Esther Duflo says it‚Äôs time to think seriously about getting billionaires to contribute
description: Nobel Prize-winning economist Esther Duflo brings her data-driven precision to the climate crisis ‚Äî and the numbers are damning. While world leaders haggle over finances at endless summits, rising temperatures will kill millions in the poorest countries by the end of this century. She calculates the staggering cost of wealthy nations pumping greenhouse gases into the atmosphere, proving that getting billionaires to pay their fair share in taxes is the best way to cover these damages.

title: The Thrill of Not Knowing All the Answers | Harini Bhat | TED
description:
In a world that prizes certainty, hot takes and instant answers, what happens when we celebrate the power of ... not knowing? Scientist and storyteller Harini Bhat shares how she built a mega-popular YouTube channel where curiosity, not credentials, drives discovery. From ancient brains turned to glass to the origins of life itself, she reminds us that science isn't just for scientists ‚Äî it's for anyone willing to ask, "Why?" (Recorded at TEDNext 2025 on November 10, 2025)

description: What happens when a mall falls into ruin? Filmmaker Dan Bell guides us through abandoned monoliths of merchandise, providing a surprisingly funny and lyrical commentary on consumerism, youth culture and the inspiration we can find in decay.

title: Profiling Pytorch/XLA on TPUs with XProf
description:
Unlock the full potential of your PyTorch models running on Google TPUs. We'll look at how to profile PyTorch/XLA workloads on TPUs using XProf, and learn how to identify and eliminate bottlenecks in your training pipeline, ensuring you're getting maximum performance from the TPU hardware.

description:

title: NumPy & JAX NumPy (Part 2)
description:

title: Debugging JAX & Flax NNX (Part 1)
description:

JAX and Flax NNX offer amazing performance and a clean API, but debugging can feel different due to JAX's compilation model. Today, we'll bridge the gap, exploring how to debug JAX and NNX effectively, relating techniques back to your PyTorch experience. We'll focus specifically on the Flax NNX API.  This is the first episode of a three episode series on debugging. title: How to secure your AI Agents: A Technical Deep-dive
description:
AI agents introduce unique security challenges like prompt injection, data leakage, and excessive agency. This workshop breaks down the OWASP LLM Top 10 and demonstrates how to implement robust security controls using Model Armor and the Agent Development Kit (ADK). Learn how to filter malicious inputs, redact sensitive data from outputs, and manage authentication patterns to build secure and reliable agentic workflows.

title: The Brains of Altruistic and Psychopathic People (W/ Abigail Marsh) | How to Be a Better Human | TED
description:
Why is American culture so fascinated with psychopathic people and true crime stories? Why don‚Äôt billionaires give more? What makes some people so generous that they‚Äôd undergo surgery to donate an organ to a complete stranger? These are the kinds of questions that Abigail Marsh, a professor of psychology and neuroscience at Georgetown University, studies. Chris and Abigail discuss the brain differences between extreme altruists and psychopathic individuals, why psychopathic traits do not necessarily correlate with aggression, how parents can support children with behavioral issues, and what we can all do to train ourselves to be more altruistic.

title: Do you ‚Äî or someone you know ‚Äî have ADHD? Here‚Äôs @HowtoADHD to help
description: Jessica McCabe tell us the story of her life. Once a gifted child with bright future, who later lives a life of a constant failures, because one thing - her ADHD diagnosis. Until one thing changed everything and she realized, that she is not alone. Her Youtube channel HowtoADHD is dedicated to help not only people with ADHD, but also their parents, partners a teachers and to remind them, that they are not alone.

title: End to End Machine Learning with AI First Colab
description:
Ready to build machine learning models faster than ever? This video dives into end-to-end machine learning with AI-First Colab, your agentic coding partner powered by Gemini. You'll see a demo of how to execute the ML lifecycle using only natural language prompts, starting from raw data and ending with full prediction of 2026 Winter Olympics medal counts. Learn how to transform your development process by letting AI handle the heavy lifting for data preparation, model training, evaluation, and prediction, allowing you to focus on high-level strategy and direction. Start your next machine learning project with unprecedented speed and ease.

Products Mentioned:  Google AI, Colab

title: How to build an AI agent with MCP, ADK, and A2A on Google Cloud
description:
Explore the powerful tools and protocols for AI agent development on Google Cloud. In this video, we dive into how to connect AI models to resources using Model Context Protocol (MCP), streamline agent creation with the Agent Development Kit (ADK), and enable seamless communication between agents with the Agent2Agent (A2A) protocol. By the end, you will have a working AI agent system, while understanding its underlying architecture.

Resources: 
Getting Started with MCP, ADK and A2A ‚Üí https://goo.gle/48scfNV 
Build with Vertex AI: Deploy Agents with Agent Development Kit (ADK), MCP, and A2A ‚Üí https://goo.gle/48LAwjm 
ADK samples GitHub ‚Üí https://goo.gle/3Y5OC96 

Chapters:
0:00 - Introduction 
0:38- Understanding ADK, A2A, and MCP
2:02 - Setting up your Google Cloud environment
3:09 - Enabling Google Cloud APIs
5:04 - Building the MCP server for tools
6:57 - Deploying the MCP server to Cloud Run
8:42 - Creating your AI agent with ADK
10:21 - Exposing your agent via A2A
12:28 - Testing the A2A communication
13:29 - Cleaning up your Google Cloud project
14:02 - Conclusion: building with AI agents

Subscribe to Google for Developers ‚Üí https://goo.gle/developers 

Speaker: Julia Wiesinger
Products Mentioned:  Google AI, Agent Development Kit (ADK)

title: Drone Vocabulary for English Learners üöÅ
description:
In this English lesson I will help you learn useful vocabulary for talking about drones and other flying technology. Maybe you've seen a drone at the park or beach or own one in real life, or you‚Äôre just curious about how they work, these words will help you describe them clearly and confidently in English.

In this English lesson you‚Äôll learn words and phrases like: drone, quadcopter, controller, gimbal, propeller, battery pack, and flight time. I‚Äôll also teach action words like hover, takeoff, and landing, as well as helpful phrases like obstacle avoidance and drone pilot.

I hope you enjoy this English lesson about drones!

title: Advanced English Grammar Quiz on Verb Tenses
description:
Test your English grammar with this fast-paced verb tense quiz!
In this B2-level lesson, we practice verb tenses and aspect (progressive and perfect forms) using real-life examples from the kitchen.
You‚Äôll review sentences with:
‚úî present progressive for frequent habits
‚úî present perfect progressive for an ongoing action
‚úî past perfect for the first of two past actions
‚úî future decisions made at the moment
Try to guess the correct meaning before the answer appears. Hit ‚Äúpause‚Äù if you need more time. 

This short lesson helps you understand verb tenses in a real, meaningful context, so you can speak and write more naturally.

title: How to Raise Confident Kids in an Age of Anxiety | Lenore Skenazy | TED
description:
The secret to reducing childhood anxiety is actually quite simple: just let kids do more stuff on their own, says Lenore Skenazy, cofounder and president of Let Grow, an organization dedicated to normalizing childhood independence. In conversation with TED‚Äôs Whitney Pennington Rodgers, Skenazy discusses why parenting has become more demanding in our safety-obsessed world ‚Äî and offers a more joyful, trusting alternative to helicopter parenting, with tangible steps for how to start safely (and sanely) letting your kids grow. title: Communicate Better with Appositives | English Grammar
description:
What is an appositive?
In this quick grammar lesson, I explain how an appositive helps rename and clarify the subject of a sentence. (Appositives can actually rename any noun, but we'll focus on subjects in this short lesson.)

You‚Äôll see clear examples featuring my colleague, a global knowledge entertainer who teaches English through rhythm and rhyme. Do you know him? Jason Levine!
We look at appositives like:
‚úî Jason Levine, a global knowledge entertainer, teaches through rhythm and rhyme. (commas used because this is additional information)
‚úî My friend Jase is good at raps and chants. (no commas used because his name explains "my friend" -- it's necessary information)

You‚Äôll also learn a common mistake to avoid: using an unnecessary object pronoun after a proper noun. This lesson can help B1+ English learners who want clearer, more natural grammar. Communicate better with standard English grammar!

Try writing your own sentence with an appositive in the comments! Be careful with your use of commas. Is the information necessary?

title: English Phrases with the Word "STEP" in Them üö∂
description:
In this English lesson, you‚Äôll learn some useful phrases that include the word ‚Äústep.‚Äù These expressions show up often in everyday conversations, and understanding them will help you sound more natural and confident. You'll learn at how to talk about progress, encouragement, and new beginnings.

In this English lesson I'll teach you phrases such as step by step, every step of the way, to take the first step, and one step at a time. These expressions are perfect when you want to talk about learning, completing tasks, or supporting someone. They help you describe how progress happens slowly, carefully, and with patience.

We‚Äôll also explore phrases about confidence and improvement, including step out of your comfort zone and a step in the right direction. These are great for talking about personal goals and small actions that lead to big results.

By the end of the lesson, you‚Äôll understand what each phrase means and how to use them naturally in your own English conversations.

‚åõ Remember:  Always watch the video three times.  Twice today with the English subtitles on, and once tomorrow with the English subtitles off.  This will reinforce the English you have learned!

title: Warning: This video might make you hungry. #Singapore #TEDx #GlobalIdeaSearch
Join local Atlanta food creator Tiery Reese for a taste of the Alps in Atlanta at Avize #TEDTalks
How to Eat with Awareness and Purpose (w/ Sean Sherman) | How to Be a Better Human | TED
description:
If you remove ingredients like dairy, wheat, flour, cane sugar, beef, pork and chicken from your diet ‚Äî then what do you eat? For Sioux chef Sean Sherman, excluding these colonial ingredients from his dishes gives him the opportunity to spotlight Indigenous produce and uplift local communities. Watch as Chris Duffy, host of the podcast ‚ÄúHow to Be a Better Human,‚Äù travels to Minneapolis, Minnesota, to meet Sherman and ethnobotanist Linda Black Elk as they talk about foraging, access to Indigenous ingredients and how food connects us to our ancestors.

This episode is part of a series of bonus videos from "How to Be a Better Human." You can find the extended interview on the TED Audio Collective YouTube Channel.

title: A? An? The? | The English Article Trick You've Never Been Told
description:
Do you still feel unsure sometimes about when to use THE, A, AN or no article at all (the "zero" article)? ü§î In this lesson, I use a memorable owl story to help you understand English articles in a meaningful context. This is the so-called trick to learning grammar. A rule or pattern must be seen in a meaningful and memorable context for it to stick! 

You‚Äôll see how articles show specific (THE) vs. generic references (A, AN, zero article), and how they depend on countable and uncountable nouns.
ü¶â What you‚Äôll learn:
‚úÖ The difference between THE, A/AN, and the zero article
Note: 
a bird (A - before a consonant sound)
an owl (AN - before a vowel sound)
‚úÖ How to choose the right article naturally
‚úÖ Why context matters when speaking or writing
‚úÖ Practice quizzes with real examples based on my story
Ideal for B2-C1 English learners who want to accurate English for confident, effective communication
‚ú® Watch, learn, and take on my bonus challenge at the end!

#EnglishGrammar #LearnEnglish #EnglishArticles #TheAAan #ZeroArticle #ESLLesson #B2English #C1English #EnglishWithJennifer #GrammarTips #SpeakEnglishNaturally

title: Are people born wicked? Or do they have wickedness thrust upon them? #TEDTalk
description: If you've ever been swept away by the worlds of "Wicked," "Hamilton" or "West Side Story," you've seen Paul Tazewell's breathtaking costumes. The Oscar-winning designer (whose work features in "Wicked: For Good") explores the subconscious language of clothing and how it shapes who we view as heroes ‚Äî and who we view as villains.

title: The Secret Language of Cells ‚Äî and How to ‚ÄúSpeak‚Äù It | Chris Bahl | TED
description:
What if medicines could "speak" directly to your cells? Protein designer and TED Fellow Chris Bahl introduces a new generation of miniproteins: AI-designed medicines that can deliver detailed instructions to fix what's making you sick. He shares how this breakthrough could potentially unlock safer, more effective treatments for some of humanity's most challenging diseases. (Recorded at TED2025 on April 9, 2025)

title: Let's Learn English! Topic: Big Tech! üñ•Ô∏èüë©‚Äçüíªü§ñ (Lesson Only)
description:
In this English lesson you'll learn some words and phrases that English speakers use when talking about Big Tech companies like Meta, Amazon, Apple, Google, Facebook, and OpenAI. These tech giants have changed the way we search for information, connect with friends, and shop so it's important to know the words and phrases people use when discussing them in English conversations.

In this English class you‚Äôll learn useful terms such as big tech, tech giants, targeted advertising, algorithm, search engine, machine learning, server farm, generative AI, data centre, privacy, user data, and cloud computing. 

By the end of this English lesson, you‚Äôll be able to speak confidently about social media platforms, new digital trends, and the rapidly changing technology around you.

I hope you enjoy this English lesson about Big Tech!

US politics are polarized ‚Äî these two governors believe there‚Äôs a better way forward #TEDTalks
description: Two current US governors ‚Äî Democrat Matt Meyer of Delaware and Republican J. Kevin Stitt of Oklahoma ‚Äî trade notes on how to rebuild trust without partisan theater. In this special segment of "On the Spot" (TED's rapid-fire Q&A format), they share thoughts on leading when people live in different realities, swapping outrage for outcomes and why we need to govern like neighbors, not enemies.

title: How Video Games Can Power Up Your Parenting | Hannah Boquet | TED
description:
Parenting an eye-rolling teenager glued to a gaming system is not a simple feat, but what if you could turn screen time into an opportunity for connection? Hannah Boquet shares how she decided to play video games with her kids and discovered the power of esports to foster trust, communication and essential life skills. Dive deeper into how you can strengthen family bonds, support your child‚Äôs development ‚Äî and maybe even be considered ‚Äúcool‚Äù by your kid. (Recorded at TEDxSioux Falls on April 18, 2025)

title: Proof that even ‚Äúpointless‚Äù projects have a purpose #TEDTalks
description: In this joyful, heartfelt talk featuring demos of her wonderfully wacky creations, Simone Giertz shares her craft: making useless robots. Her inventions -- designed to chop vegetables, cut hair, apply lipstick and more -- rarely (if ever) succeed, and that's the point. "The true beauty of making useless things [is] this acknowledgment that you don't always know what the best answer is," Giertz says. "It turns off that voice in your head that tells you that you know exactly how the world works. Maybe a toothbrush helmet isn't the answer, but at least you're asking the question."

title: Learn Passive Gerunds | B2-C1 Grammar Made Easy
description:
How can we use a phrase like ‚Äúbeing told‚Äù?
In this short English lesson, you‚Äôll learn what passive gerunds are and how to form them using being + past participle (being told, being seen, being criticized).
You‚Äôll also hear natural examples like:
‚úî I don‚Äôt like being seen without my makeup.
‚úî I hated being teased as a child.
‚úî Being complimented is nice when it‚Äôs sincere.

Practice in the comments by completing my prompts:
I don‚Äôt like being‚Ä¶
I truly hate being‚Ä¶
This lesson is ideal for B2+ learners who want clearer, more natural grammar in everyday English.

title: Whether you leave or stay, your hometown is a part of you #TEDTalks #HowToBeABetterHuman
description: Loving where you live means caring for the people who make that place home, says cultural critic Hanif Abdurraqib. He invites poet Sarah Kay and Chris Duffy, host of the podcast ‚ÄúHow to Be a Better Human,‚Äù to his hometown of Columbus, Ohio, to show off what makes it so special. From sneaker shops and record stores to public parks, Abdurraqib talks about how he builds community ‚Äî and how anyone can learn to love their hometown.

title: How to Pull the Emergency Brake on Global Warming | Mohamed A. Sultan | TED
description:
Landfills across African cities are catching fire and releasing methane, an invisible greenhouse gas with more short-term warming potential than CO2. Sustainable strategist Mohamed A. Sultan reveals how local communities are turning this crisis into opportunity, diverting hundreds of tons of waste from landfills and helping thousands of farmers adopt more sustainable techniques. Learn why cutting methane emissions is a win-win opportunity to drive down global temperatures while also creating more livable cities. (This ambitious idea is part of The Audacious Project, TED‚Äôs initiative to inspire and fund global change.) (Recorded at TED Countdown Summit 2025 on June 16, 2025)

title: What does the English phrase 'go the extra mile' mean? - Do you want to learn English?
description:
Here is an interesting English phrase that we use when we want to express putting more effort or showing extra motivation to help someone or do something. The phrase I'm talking about is 'go the extra mile'. This particular phrase is often used when we want to express doing much more than is actually needed. To go that extra mile means to put yourself outmore than you normally would. When we say 'put yourself out', we mean you are going to extra trouble to do something. Perhaps you have a plan, but instead you decide to help your neighbour move some furniture. You are putting yourself outfor your neighbour. You might also say that you are going the extra mile. You don't have to do that particular thing, but you decide that it is a good thing to do. Despite the fact that it will cause you some inconvenience, in your job, you might go the extra mile to make your boss happy. You put more effort into your workthan you actually need to. Sometimes there is a reasonwhy a person will go the extra mile. Perhaps that person wants to appearkind and generous. Maybe they want to make a good impressionon others. In both of those situations,you will try to go the extra mile. We can also say that a person 'goes that extra mile'. They will do more than is necessary. You can 'go the extra mile' or 'go that extra mile'. Both forms of the phrase mean the same thing.
Of course, going the extra mile is not always a selfish action. However, if you want to be
noticed and liked, then sometimes it is necessary to go that extra mile. A little extra effort can go a long way.

(About Mr Duncan)

title: How to Love Your Hometown (w/ Hanif Abdurraqib and Sarah Kay) | How to Be a Better Human | TED
description:
Loving where you live means caring for the people who make that place home, says cultural critic Hanif Abdurraqib. He invites poet Sarah Kay and Chris Duffy, host of the podcast ‚ÄúHow to Be a Better Human,‚Äù to his hometown of Columbus, Ohio, to show off what makes it so special. From sneaker shops and record stores to public parks, Abdurraqib talks about how he builds community ‚Äî and how anyone can learn to love their hometown.

This episode is part of a series of bonus videos from "How to Be a Better Human." You can find the extended interview on the TED Audio Collective YouTube Channel.

description: You might think you‚Äôre an expert at email, but you‚Äôre probably doing it wrong. Which greeting should you use? How can you make sure you‚Äôre not misunderstood? Do you know the golden rule of CC? From subject line to sign-off, Victoria Turk guides through some of the oft-neglected fundamentals of email etiquette. Victoria Turk is a senior editor at WIRED UK, where she edits the magazine's culture section, leads video strategy, and writes regularly for print and web. She specialises in stories at the intersection of technology and culture, which explore the impact of technology on our everyday lives.

title: Two US Governors ‚Äî a Democrat and a Republican ‚Äî on Why There‚Äôs Hope for Democracy | On the Spot
description:
Two current US governors ‚Äî Democrat Matt Meyer of Delaware and Republican J. Kevin Stitt of Oklahoma ‚Äî trade notes on how to rebuild trust without partisan theater. In this special segment of "On the Spot" (TED's rapid-fire Q&A format), they share thoughts on leading when people live in different realities, swapping outrage for outcomes and why we need to govern like neighbors, not enemies. (Recorded at TEDNext 2025 on November 10, 2025)

description:

title: How We‚Äôre Turning Pollution into Toys, Toothpaste and More | Xu Hao | TED
description:
It took alcohol 200 years to go from scientific discovery to industrial revolution, but tech innovator Xu Hao says we can‚Äôt afford to wait that long to tackle the climate crisis. He explores why most climate solutions are still stuck in labs ‚Äî despite breakthrough science that can turn planet-warming CO2 into everyday products like toothpaste, water bottles and smartphone components ‚Äî and explains what it will take for a clean future to arrive sooner than we think. (Recorded at TED Countdown Summit 2025 on June 17, 2025)

title: If You Can Understand These Two Jokes Your English Level Is Amazing! ü§™ü§£üòÜ
description:
One of the best ways to test your English comprehension is to listen to a few jokes. Jokes hold meaning on two levels. They have literal meaning, which most can understand, and they have a secondary meaning which is what makes them funny. As an English learner, if you can understand why a joke is funny, it means your ability to understand English is very well developed.

In this English lesson I will tell you two longer jokes that were first told to me by my uncle when I was a kid. I've also included on dad joke as well.

I hope these jokes help you learn a bit more English, and maybe you can even try to tell one of these jokes to an English speaking friend. Have a great day!

‚åõ Remember:  Always watch the video three times.  Twice today with the English subtitles on, and once tomorrow with the English subtitles off.  This will reinforce the English you have learned!

description:

This is an ongoing study program. Members vote on a monthly topic. All skills are addressed. 

Learn how to sound more natural in English by mastering word stress in reflexive and impersonal pronouns as well as how to group your words into thought groups for smoother, clearer speech.

In this accent reduction lesson, I continue to work with Nitish, a student from India, to practice natural stress and rhythm in his self-introduction.

Together,  let's practice how to:
‚úî Say pronouns in context
‚úî Use thought groups to organize ideas while speaking
‚úî Use intonation and rhythm for clarity
‚úî Build confidence to speak more naturally and fluently

This series is for intermediate and advanced learners who want to reduce their accent, strengthen rhythm, and improve pronunciation in real communication.

#AccentReduction #LearnEnglish #AmericanAccent #EnglishPronunciation #WordStress #ThoughtGroups #EnglishWithJennifer #ESL #SpeakEnglishNaturally #PronunciationPractice

title: If You Can Understand These Jokes Your English Level Is Very High! üåº üö≤üëñüìò (Lesson Only)
description:
In this English lesson, I‚Äôll be sharing 20 jokes to help you test your English skills in a fun way. If you can understand why the jokes are funny and they make you laugh, it‚Äôs a great sign that your English level is quite advanced. Being able to get jokes in another language means you truly understand the language and the joke!

In this lesson, I‚Äôll tell jokes about all kinds of things: computers, bicycles, graveyards, pants, homework, golf, the moon, grapes, numbers, pictures, facial hair, trees, scarecrows, and more! You‚Äôll not only learn some funny jokes, but you‚Äôll also pick up new English words and phrases along the way.

I hope you enjoy this English lesson filled with laughter and learning. Have a great day!

title: TED Talks Daily Book Club: Intentional Ambition | Rha Goddess | TED
description:
Rha Goddess is an entrepreneurial soul coach and author of the new book "Intentional Ambition: Redefining Your Work for Greater Joy, Freedom, and Fulfillment." In this TED Talks Daily Book Club interview with host Elise Hu, Goddess talks about the most profound, unspoken shifts that the 2020 pandemic generated ‚Äî and how you can center your life around achieving greater joy and mental wellbeing. She lays out the three stages to renegotiate your relationship to work in order to discover and align with your true ambitions. Later in the conversation, she answers questions from the TED community and offers advice on how to recognize your mission and values while leading with compassion. (The TED Talks Daily Book Club series features TED speakers discussing their latest books and exploring their ideas beyond the page. ‚úî Improve pronunciation and listening

üí°10 Natural Ways to Say "I'm tired."

I‚Äôm so drained. I‚Äôm going to call it a night. 

I‚Äôm bushed. I‚Äôm calling it a night.

I‚Äôm totally dead. I‚Äôm going to crash.

I can‚Äôt keep my eyes open. I‚Äôm going to crash for the night.

I can‚Äôt stop yawning. Time for me to hit the sack. 

Well, I‚Äôm going to head to bed. I‚Äôm pooped.

I‚Äôm done for the day. I‚Äôm going to turn in.

Time for me to hit the hay, as they say. I‚Äôm already half asleep. 

Oh, I need to get some shut-eye. I‚Äôm plain worn out.

I need to lie down and catch some Z‚Äôs. G‚Äônight.

title: Birds of a feather‚Ä¶ FaceTime together! #TEDTalks
description: Imagine this: you walk into a room, and your dog is on a video call with their fellow canine friends. Computer scientist Ilyena Hirskyj-Douglas thinks the notion of a social internet for animals is not far off. She explores what happens when animals control their own technology ‚Äî from parrots making friends online to monkeys choosing their favorite audio tracks ‚Äî and shows how this technology transforms our understanding of animal consciousness.

title: The Flourishing Future of Women‚Äôs Sports | Kate Johnson | TED
description:
Women's sports are surging in popularity around the world, with record-breaking viewership, attendance and revenue growth. And yet, social media algorithms still skew towards covering men's sports. Olympic rower Kate Johnson, who now leads global marketing strategy for sports and entertainment at Google, unpacks why this is still happening ‚Äî and what it will take to level the playing field for women‚Äôs sports. (Recorded at TEDSports Indianapolis 2025 on September 10, 2025)

title: How to Recapture the Joy of the Early Internet | Michael Sun | TED
description:
Before algorithms ruled our feeds, the internet was a mess ‚Äî glitchy, chaotic and full of unexpected magic. Internet culture writer Michael Sun reflects on the wild digital world of the 2000s ‚Äî and makes a funny, wry case for why we need to reclaim its spontaneity, weirdness and genuine connection. From niche Facebook groups to loading music onto your iPod, it might be time to borrow from the past. (Recorded at TEDxYouth@Sydneyon May 24, 2023)

title: How Americans Really Say "What?" and "Don't"
description:
Learn how to sound more natural in American English by mastering the glottal stop ‚Äî that quick sound Americans use instead of a clear /t/ in words like "What?" or many of the negative contractions (can't, don't, haven't, etc.).

In this short accent training video, I'll show you three easy techniques to understand and pronounce the glottal stop correctly.
This lesson is ideal for English learners who want to:
‚úî Understand American English speakers
‚úî Speak naturally and confidently in American English
Watch, repeat, and practice these sounds until they become natural!

title: Tax the Rich ‚Äî and Save the Planet | Esther Duflo | TED
description:
Nobel Prize-winning economist Esther Duflo brings her data-driven precision to the climate crisis ‚Äî and the numbers are damning. While world leaders haggle over finances at endless summits, rising temperatures will kill millions in the poorest countries by the end of this century. She calculates the staggering cost of wealthy nations pumping greenhouse gases into the atmosphere, proving that getting billionaires to pay their fair share in taxes is the best way to cover these damages. (Recorded at TED Countdown Summit 2025 on June 18, 2025)

title: Most People Don't Know These English Words And Phrases About Bad Weather ‚òîüåßÔ∏èüí¶
description:
In this English lesson, you‚Äôll learn how to talk about bad weather in a casual, everyday way and also in a more formal way you might hear on the news. 

When it‚Äôs raining or snowing, we use all kinds of expressions to describe how awful it feels outside. You‚Äôll hear people say things like ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs miserable out there,‚Äù ‚ÄúWhat a gross day,‚Äù or ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a crappy day.‚Äù These are all informal ways to describe bad weather when you‚Äôre chatting with friends or coworkers.

You‚Äôll also learn how to sound more formal when talking about weather conditions. In the news or in official announcements, people often use terms like ‚Äúadverse weather conditions‚Äù or ‚Äúinclement weather.‚Äù These phrases are useful in reports, emails, or work situations where you need to sound professional or polite, even when the weather is terrible!

Finally, we‚Äôll look at common actions and phrases people use during rain or snow. When it rains, you might ‚Äúget caught in the rain‚Äù or ‚Äúbe drenched‚Äù by the time you get home. In snowy weather, you could ‚Äúgo in the ditch‚Äù or ‚Äúslip and fall‚Äù on the ice. You‚Äôll even learn sports expressions like ‚Äúa rain delay‚Äù or ‚Äúto be rained out.‚Äù

By the end of this lesson, you‚Äôll be ready to describe any kind of rainy or snowy day in both formal and informal English!

I hope you enjoy this English lesson about bad weather!

‚åõ Remember:  Always watch the video three times.  Twice today with the English subtitles on, and once tomorrow with the English subtitles off.  This will reinforce the English you have learned!

title: Let's Learn English! Topic: Handy Machines! ü§ñüèßüí¶ (Lesson Only)
description:
In this English lesson, you‚Äôll learn vocabulary about handy machines, the everyday devices that make our lives simpler and more convenient. From the vending machine that serves you a quick snack to the reverse vending machine that gives you money back, these clever inventions are all around us, quietly helping us every day.

In this English lesson, you‚Äôll learn words and phrases like: automatic door, robotic lawn mower, garage door opener, car wash, self-checkout, cash counter, escalator, smart plug, vending machine, reverse vending machine, ATM, water fountain, and more!

By the end of this lesson, you‚Äôll be able to describe and talk about modern conveniences easily and naturally in English. Whether you‚Äôre explaining how an automatic door works or asking someone where the nearest ATM is, you‚Äôll sound fluent and confident when talking about technology that makes life a little smoother.

I hope you enjoy this English lesson all about handy machines!

title: A peek inside the minds behind true crime #TEDTalks
description: Psychopathic killers are the basis for some must-watch TV, but what really makes them tick? Neuroscientist Jim Fallon talks about brain scans and genetic analysis that may uncover the rotten wiring in the nature (and nurture) of murderers. In a too-strange-for-fiction twist, he shares a fascinating family history that makes his work chillingly personal.

title: The line between contagion and connection is much thinner than you may realize
description: After a mysterious wave of tics and twitches swept through a small-town high school in New York, documentary podcaster Dan Taberski set out to investigate what was really happening. Drawing on extensive research and intimate interviews with the people involved, he explores the roots of mass hysteria ‚Äî and what it reveals about the line between illness and belonging. What happens when the very thing that makes us sick ... is also what connects us?

title: How Do Americans Really Speak? | üëªSCREAM English Pronunciation Analysis (üéÉ Halloween Special üéÉ)
description:
Take my FREE course to improve your American English here: https://tinyurl.com/free-course-921

üéÉ Happy (almost) Halloween! In this special edition Ben Franklin exercise¬Æ we‚Äôre taking a short conversation clip from the movie *Scream* and diving deep in to how Americans really speak.  

If you‚Äôre a moderate to advanced English learner ready to move beyond mere fluency into conversational native-sound speech, this lesson is for you.

In this video you‚Äôll learn how stress, tempo, reductions, linking, schwas and placement all combine to give spoken American English its unique rhythm and sound. We‚Äôll use phonetic symbols (IPA) and on-screen notation so you can visually see how the native speaker pronounces each word and phrase!

üìå What you‚Äôll get:
- A short real native speaker dialogue from Scream  
- On-screen IPA/transcription and notation of reductions & linking  
- Sentences and phrases you can pause and repeat with your own voice  
- Bonus: Halloween-themed clip to make pronunciation study more fun!

üí° How to get the most from this lesson:
1. Watch the clip once without stopping to get the ‚Äúfeel‚Äù of the clip.  
2. Re-watch with the on-screen IPA and notation, and pause when needed ‚Äî try to imitate exactly.  
3. Record yourself saying the same lines and compare your rhythm, linking and reductions with the original.  
4. Try using variations of the phrase in your own conversations: how would you say it?

üëç If you liked this lesson, don‚Äôt forget to subscribe and hit the bell for new videos every week.  

Happy studying ‚Äî and happy Halloween! üëª 

Learn more: https://rachelsenglish.com/how-do-americans-really-speak-%f0%9f%91%bbscream-movie-%f0%9f%98%b1clip-english-pronunciation-analysis-%f0%9f%8e%83-halloween-special-%f0%9f%8e%83/

title: Learn 19 Funny English Words and Phrases for Everyday Life!
description:
Preply is a great way to find an English conversation partner. Find the perfect tutor to help you make real progress on your English learning journey! Use this link: http://preply.sjv.io/vPYYeL to get 50% off your first lesson or use code BOB50 at checkout. In my experience Preply is a great way to take your language learning to the next level!

In this English lesson, you‚Äôll learn some fun words and phrases that native English speakers love to use! These expressions help you sound more natural when talking about habits, moods, and personalities ‚Äî especially in casual conversation. From weather and sleep to social life and driving, you‚Äôll discover how these short phrases add color to your English.

In this English class I'll help you learn English words and phrases like: sweater weather, passenger princess, backseat driver, party pooper, couch potato, beauty sleep, happy camper, early bird, night owl, social butterfly, homebody, city slicker, country bumpkin, neat freak, copycat, and know-it-all, quiet time and me time.

This English lesson is full of examples, explanations, and pronunciation practice so you can use these phrases naturally in your daily conversations. Whether you‚Äôre a social butterfly or more of a homebody, you‚Äôll have fun learning!

title: English Rewind - 6 Minute English: Ghost writers
description:
üìª What does the English verb 'to ghost write' mean? It's nothing to do with ghost stories, ghost trains or ghost towns! And why do celebrities these days tend to use ghost writers to write their life stories for them? Learn more while you improve your English vocabulary knowledge AND practise your English listening with this archive episode of the BBC Learning English programme 6 Minute English. Do you read books by celebrity authors? Tell us in the comments üëáüëáüëá

Useful vocabulary:
‚úîÔ∏è ghost write - write a book or article for another person, so they can pretend that they wrote it.
‚úîÔ∏è no-holds-barred - without any limits or controls
‚úîÔ∏è stilted style - style that doesn't flow very well, and doesn't sound natural or elegant
‚úîÔ∏è coherent - well-structured
‚úîÔ∏è to be credited - to have your contribution to something (for example, writing a book) acknowledged
‚úîÔ∏è becoming more mainstream - becoming more widely known and accepted
‚úîÔ∏è stepping out of the closet - becoming known, no longer a secret
‚úîÔ∏è to  be savvy - if you're savvy about something, you know and understand it

Image: Getty
English Rewind is a collection of programmes from the BBC Learning English archive. This episode of 6 Minute English was first published on the BBC Learning English website in June 2008.

title: Let's Learn English! Topic: Animal Sounds! üêÑüêñü¶Ü (Lesson Only)
description:
I thought it would be fun to make a lighthearted English lesson about animals and the sounds they make. You probably already know many of these animals and their sounds, but I think you'll still enjoy hearing me say the words and try to imitate the sounds!

In this lesson, you‚Äôll learn animal sound words like:

quack: the sound of a duck
moo: the sound of a cow
neigh: the sound of a horse
bark: the sound of a dog
meow: the sound of a cat
honk: the sound of a goose
oink: the sound of a pig
roar: the sound of a lion
baa: the sound of a sheep
woof: another sound of a dog
whinny: another sound of a horse
crow: the sound of a rooster
cluck: the sound of a chicken
croak: the sound of a frog
ribbit: another sound of a frog

I hope you have a great time learning English with these fun animal sounds!

‚åõ Remember:  Always watch the video three times.  Twice today with the English subtitles on, and once tomorrow with the English subtitles off.  This will reinforce the English you have learned!

title: What does 'bumper' mean? Explaining the use of bumper in English, with Mr Duncan. #englishlanguage
description:
Today's English lesson... It really has been an interesting year for all of the plants and trees growing here in England, including right here in my garden. One of the most obvious differences this year must be the amount of fruit produced on the trees at the back of my house. The amount of fruit produced this year has been outstanding to say the least, with much larger than usual crops of both apples and damsons, both of which grow freely right here in the garden. The mild and wet spring as well as the hot and at times rainy summer have helped to produce an almost overwhelming amount of fruit. There is an interesting word we can use to describe something that is more than usual, especially when we are talking about quantity. We can use the word ‚Äòbumper‚Äô to describe this particular occurrence.

Mr Duncan has been teaching English for free on YouTube for over 18 years. Have fun learning English as a second language. Captions are available. #englishaddictwithmrduncan #mrduncanenglish #duncanenglish #misterduncan #mrduncantheenglishaddict

title: 'Do you care?' -  Express CARE in English. How to use the word 'care'. #mrduncanenglish
description:
Are you ready to learn English? Here is an interesting word that at first glance might seem simple. However, this particular word has many meanings. Today's word is care. C A R E. Care. As I just said, this particular word can be used in many ways. First, as a noun, the word care means the provision of what is necessary for health, welfare, maintenance, and protection of someone or something. Learn the many meanings of English words with Mr Duncan in England.

title: An English Lesson about the Great Outdoors! üå≥üåøüçÇ
description:
In this English lesson, you‚Äôll learn phrases and vocabulary about nature and the great outdoors! üå≥üåøüçÇ

If you love spending time outside, this lesson will help you talk about it in English! We‚Äôll explore useful nature words and phrases like the great outdoors, Mother Nature, fresh air, wide open spaces, the wilderness, natural habitat, flora and fauna, and the elements.

You‚Äôll not only learn what each term means, but also how to use them in real English sentences. Whether you enjoy hiking, camping, or just taking a quiet walk in the park, these phrases will help you sound more natural when talking about the beauty of the world around us. 

I hope you enjoy this English lesson about the great outdoors.

‚åõ Remember:  Always watch the video three times.  Twice today with the English subtitles on, and once tomorrow with the English subtitles off.  This will reinforce the English you have learned!

title: American English T: Why the Name 'Peter' Sounds Like 'Peeder'
description:
‚ú®Are you an advanced student? Would you like LIVE instruction every month and meaningful practice with my feedback?
Join me on Patreon. üëâhttp://patreon.com/englishwithjennifer

This is an ongoing study program. Members vote on a monthly topic. All skills are addressed. 


In this accent reduction lesson, I work with Nitish, a student from India, to practice word stress in common boys‚Äô and girls‚Äô names and review the flap T (that quick ‚Äúd‚Äù sound you hear in words like "water" and "city").
I'll help you learn how to:
‚úî Say the correct stress pattern in common names  
‚úî Improve your listening and your ability to hear stressed syllables
‚úî Sound clearer and more confident in American English
Ideal for intermediate and advanced learners who want to reduce their accent in American English. 

Follow Nitish's journey! Will we get to vowel and consonant sounds as well as intonation and linking? Yes! A lot of fun pronunciation activities are coming up as well as we start to put everything together. 

#AccentReduction #AmericanAccent #LearnEnglish #EnglishPronunciation #FlapT #WordStress #EnglishWithJennifer #ESL #SpeakEnglishNaturally #pronunciationpractice

title: Let's Learn English! Topic: Fitness Snacks and Drinks! üßÉ‚ö°üç´ (Lesson Only)
description:
In this English lesson, you‚Äôll learn some popular words and phrases we use to talk about fitness snacks and drinks. When people work out, go for a run, or hit the gym, they often have special foods and beverages that help them stay strong, energized, and hydrated.

In this lesson, you‚Äôll learn useful terms like: protein shake, energy drink, smoothie, green smoothie, protein bar, to hydrate, electrolytes, meal replacement bar, trail mix, and protein powder. These are great words to know if you like talking about fitness, healthy living, or what people eat and drink to stay fit and active.

I hope you enjoy this English lesson about fitness snacks and drinks!

title: What does the phrase 'burn your bridges' mean? Learn English phrases #mrduncanenglish #learnenglish
description:
Today we will look at another interesting English phrase. What does it mean to burn your bridges? A moment of anger or a sudden change can cause you to burn your bridges. The effect of something you do might last forever. Learn English phrases with Mr Duncan.

title: Native Speakers‚Äô Secrets to Sounding Natural in English
description:
‚ú® Need a presentation, website, or carousel fast? Let AI handle the design while you focus on growth. Try it now: https://gamma.app/ 

Are you afraid to sound awkward or unnatural when you speak English?
Here‚Äôs the truth: the smartest, most confident speakers don‚Äôt use complicated words ‚Äî they use psychology.

In this video, I share 6 research-backed language tricks that will completely change the way you speak English.
You‚Äôll learn how to sound smarter without memorizing fancy vocabulary ‚Äî just by changing how you pause, connect ideas, and structure your thoughts.

title: 52 Words with Multiple Pronunciations in American English
description:
#englishwithjennifer #pronunciation #americanenglish 
Did you know that many words in English can be said different ways? Which pronunciation is right? In this video, I present 52 words with multiple pronunciations. The different variations are acceptable in American English. This list is not complete, by the way. I'm already compiling a second list we can study together in the future.
