title: Describing Bad Behaviour in English
description:
In this English lesson, you‚Äôll learn how to describe bad behaviour in English using phrases that English speakers use every day. Sometimes people disappoint us, say unkind things, or act selfishll and it‚Äôs helpful to know how to talk about those situations clearly and politely in English.

We‚Äôll look at common expressions such as to disappoint someone, to let someone down, and to hurt someone‚Äôs feelings. You‚Äôll also learn expressions like to talk behind someone‚Äôs back, to throw someone under the bus, and to take advantage of someone. I'll make sure that each phrase includes clear examples so you can understand both the meaning and how to use it naturally in conversation.

By the end of this lesson, you‚Äôll feel more confident talking about bad behaviour in English in your next English conversation! Have a great day!

‚åõ Remember:  Always watch the video three times.  Twice today with the English subtitles on, and once tomorrow with the English subtitles off.  This will reinforce the English you have learned!

title: 'Much of a Muchness' | What does this English phrase mean? #mrduncanenglish #englishlanguage
description:
Learn English phrases for the real world. What does the phrase 'much of a muchness mean? The over availability of something or a selection with no variation might be described as a much of a muchness. The available things are all similar. To have no difference in appearance or style. The word 'much' can be used in many ways. 

Mr Duncan has been teaching English for free on YouTube for over 18 years. Have fun learning English as a second language. Captions are available. #englishaddictwithmrduncan #mrduncanenglish #duncanenglish #misterduncan #mrduncantheenglishaddict #learnenglish #englishlanguage

title: British work traditions
What is your level of English? An important English lesson. #mrduncanenglish
description:
What is your level of English? In this English lesson I will explain all the levels of English learning. From A1 - A2 - B1 - B2 - C1 - C2. How long does it take to learn English to the C2 level? In this English lesson... What is Your English Level?  CEFR Levels Explained (A1-C2)  CEFR stands for Common European Framework of Reference for Languages. The Common European Framework of References for Languages (CEFR) is an international standard for language ability and comprehension. This standard includes 6 distinct English levels: A1, A2, B1, B2, C1, and C2.

ABOUT MR DUNCAN...
Mr Duncan has been teaching English for free on YouTube for over 18 years. Have fun learning English as a second language. Captions are available. #IELTS #learnenglish #mrduncanenglish #duncanenglish #misterduncan #mrduncantheenglishaddict #englishlesson #learningenglish

title: I Do Not Feel Like Making An English Lesson
description:
In this English lesson you‚Äôll learn five common ways to say that you don‚Äôt want to do something. Native speakers use these short and natural expressions all the time when they‚Äôre tired, unmotivated, or just not interested. By the end of this lesson you‚Äôll know how to recognize them and use them yourself in everyday conversations.

In this lesson you‚Äôll hear examples of: 
I don‚Äôt want to ‚Äì the most direct way to say no.
I don‚Äôt feel like it ‚Äì when you simply don‚Äôt have the desire.
I‚Äôd rather not ‚Äì a more polite refusal.
I can‚Äôt be bothered ‚Äì a casual way to say you don‚Äôt have the energy.
I don‚Äôt feel up to it ‚Äì when you‚Äôre too tired or unwell to do something.

I‚Äôll give you simple definitions, clear example sentences, and helpful pronunciation so you can feel confident using these phrases the next time you need to say no in English.

I hope you enjoy this English lesson about not wanting to do something! Have a great day!

‚åõ Remember:  Always watch the video three times.  Twice today with the English subtitles on, and once tomorrow with the English subtitles off.  This will reinforce the English you have learned!

title: How to speak without saying anything. (word salad) Speak like a politician  #learnenglish
description:
Is it possible to speak without saying anything? Can we really use words without actually putting across any message? You might be surprised to find out that it is possible to speak without conveying any real meaning. A person might talk for a long period of time using various types of sentences. However, the things they say have very little value. Those words are merely being used to fill up a certain moment. There are many situations where this might happen. In English, we often refer to this as a ‚Äòword salad‚Äô. A person speaks without conveying any important information. Quite often this occurs when someone has been put in a difficult position, where an answer to an awkward question is required.  #learnenglish #englishlanguage #speakenglish 


Mr Duncan has been teaching English for free on YouTube for over 18 years. Have fun learning English as a second language. Captions are available. #englishaddictwithmrduncan #mrduncanenglish  #duncanenglish #misterduncan #mrduncantheenglishaddict

title: Top English Number Phrases With Easy Examples
description:
Preply is a great way to find an English conversation partner. Find the perfect tutor to help you make real progress on your English learning journey! Use this link: http://preply.sjv.io/e1XbJ1 to get 50% off your first lesson or use code BOB50 at checkout. In my experience Preply is a great way to take your language learning to the next level!

In this English lesson I will help you learn phrases that have numbers in them. Have you ever heard someone say they were feeling 100% or that they wanted to split something 50/50? In English, we often use numbers in everyday expressions.

In this lesson, I‚Äôll teach you some of the most common number phrases in English, explain their meanings, and give you clear examples so you can start using them right away.

You‚Äôll learn useful expressions like giving 110%, to go halfsies, to rate something out of 10, to feel 100%, to be one in a million, to be second to none, and more. These phrases are common in conversations, movies, TV shows, and even at work. By understanding them, you‚Äôll sound more natural and confident when you speak English.

I hope you enjoy this English lesson on number phrases! Have a great day!

title: Master Word Stress Patterns: Adjectives, Adverbs & Compound Nouns
description:
#englishwithjennifer #accentreduction #americanenglish 
Follow the journey of Nitish, a real student from India, and learn to reduce the influence of your first language in order to speak English more clearly and naturally. In this tenth lesson, we practice word stress patterns with adverbs, longer adjectives, and compound nouns. We're learning to create natural rhythm in English. 

Will we get to vowel and consonant sounds as well as intonation and linking? Yes! A lot of fun pronunciation activities are coming up as well as we start to put everything together.

description:
In this English lesson we‚Äôre going to explore compound nouns. These are nouns that are created by combining two words to form a single idea. In particular, we‚Äôll focus on open compound nouns, which are written with a space between the words.

During this English class you‚Äôll learn useful examples such as: wedding reception, juice box, guest room, window frame, window pane, award ceremony, travel agent, bus stop, bowling alley, birthday cake, hospital bed, movie theatre, coffee shop, and many others.

title: Let's Learn English! Topic: Compound Nouns! üéÇüõíüöè
description:
In this English lesson we'll look at compound nouns. These are nouns that are made using two words. Specifically we'll be looking at open compound nouns where there is a space between the two words.

In this English class you'll learn words like: shopping cart, travel agent, bus stop, bowling alley, birthday cake, hospital bed, wedding reception, science lab, movie theatre, award ceremony, coffee shop, and many more.

I hope you enjoy this English lesson about compound nouns. Have a great day!

title: How to Talk about Annoying People in English
description:
In this English lesson, I‚Äôll teach you 8 common phrases we use to describe the kinds of things that people do that are a bit annoying. From bosses at work to parents at home, these expressions will help you talk about annoying behavior in English in a natural way.

In this free English class you'll learn these phrases:

-to nitpick: to complain about small, unimportant details.
-to be on someone‚Äôs case: to pressure or remind someone repeatedly about something.
-to micromanage: to control every small step of someone‚Äôs work instead of trusting them.
-to split hairs: to argue over tiny details that don‚Äôt really matter.
-to harp on someone: to complain about the same thing again and again.
-to look over someone‚Äôs shoulder: to closely watch or supervise someone while they work.
-to hound someone: to keep pressuring or bothering someone about something.
-to pick something apart: to point out all the mistakes or flaws in something.

By the end of this lesson, you‚Äôll be able to recognize these expressions and use them in your own conversations. These are very natural phrases that native English speakers use all the time, so learning them will help you sound more fluent.

I hope you enjoyed this English lesson about annoying people!

‚åõ Remember:  Always watch the video three times.  Twice today with the English subtitles on, and once tomorrow with the English subtitles off.  This will reinforce the English you have learned!

title: Gain 15 Minutes of Practice with Word Stress | Accent Training
description:
#englishwithjennifer #accentreduction #americanenglish 
Follow the journey of Nitish, a real student from India, and learn to reduce the influence of your first language in order to speak English more clearly and naturally. In this ninth lesson, we practice word stress patterns with nouns, verbs, and adjectives.

Will we get to vowel and consonant sounds as well as intonation and linking? Yes! A lot of fun pronunciation activities are coming up as well as we start to put everything together. 

CHAPTERS
0:00 Introduction
0:26 Review: How do we stress a syllable?
1:46 Learning stress patterns
2:38 Drill: Listen and repeat. 2-syllable nouns.
4:32 Drill: Listen and repeat. 2-syllable verbs.
6:04 Practice 1:1 with me.
7:42 Exceptions: words that break the patterns.
10:45 Word stress in adjectives
14:56 A note on etymology (word origin)
15:22 Practice 1:1 with me.
15:46 Where to gain more practice with me

Thanks to Nitish for coming on camera with me! Follow him on Instagram. @nitish.malhotraa

Watch more short and long videos in my pronunciation playlist.

description:
In this English lesson we‚Äôre going to explore a variety of expressions and vocabulary that use the word ‚Äúkick.‚Äù You might be surprised at just how many everyday phrases include this little word, and how their meanings can be quite different depending on the context. Thanks to Mohd Ags for suggesting this fun topic! I‚Äôll make sure to introduce each phrase, explain what it means, and show you a picture to help lock the meaning in your memory.

title: Don‚Äôt Put It Off! üìù English Vocabulary for Procrastination & Deadlines
description:
In this English lesson you‚Äôll learn useful phrases and expressions we use when talking about procrastination and doing things late. I‚Äôll explain what it means to procrastinate, to put something off, to do something at the last minute, and many other natural phrases.

You‚Äôll hear real-life examples like renewing a passport too late, not changing lanes soon enough to make an exit, or dragging your feet when you don‚Äôt feel like cleaning the house. These phrases will help you understand everyday English conversations and describe your own habits more clearly.

We‚Äôll also look at common words and expressions connected to deadlines and time pressure, such as cutting it close, to waste time, and to run out of time.

By the end of this lesson, you‚Äôll be able to talk about procrastination with confidence and recognize these expressions when native speakers use them. Don‚Äôt put it off! Watch the video now and practice your English today!

I hope you enjoyed this English lesson about procrastination and deadlines. Have a great day!

‚åõ Remember:  Always watch the video three times.  Twice today with the English subtitles on, and once tomorrow with the English subtitles off.  This will reinforce the English you have learned!

title: What Are Content Words? | American Accent Training
description:
#englishwithjennifer #accentreduction #americanenglish 
Follow the journey of Nitish, a real student from India, and learn to reduce the influence of your first language in order to speak English more clearly. In this eighth lesson, we continue our work on word stress and begin to talk about content words vs. function words.

Will we get to vowel and consonant sounds as well as intonation and linking? Yes! A lot of fun pronunciation activities are coming up as well as we start to put everything together.

description:
In this English lesson you‚Äôll learn some common English words that have two different meanings. These can sometimes be confusing for learners, since the word being used has to be determined by the context of the conversation sometimes. By the end of this class, you‚Äôll know how to identify both meanings, understand the context, and use them naturally in your own conversations. I‚Äôll also share helpful example sentences and show you how to pronounce each word clearly.

In this lesson you‚Äôll come across words like: bat, bark, spring, date, seal, nail, watch, jam, wave, light, match, fair, letter, park, tie, and many others.

For every word, I‚Äôll give you a picture, a simple explanation, and practical example sentences so you can hear exactly how native speakers use them in everyday English.

I hope you enjoy this free English lesson about words with two meanings!

description:

The actual owner of the JavaScript trademark didn't create it, doesn't maintain it and isn't even involved in its ongoing development.

But Ryan Dahl, creator of Node.js and Deno is trying to change that, even if it means waging a legal battle against a corporation with unlimited resources.

In today's video, we'll breakdown the crazy battle between Deno and Oracle to control the JavaScript trademark.

title: Let's Learn English at the Shopping Plaza / Strip Mall
description:
In this English lesson we'll go to a shopping plaza / strip mall! This is part two of a lesson I did a few months ago.  Many of you enjoyed it and asked for another.  

In my part of the English speaking world we have what are called strip malls or shopping plazas. These are places where all the shops and stores are in a row with the door facing the parking lot. Walk with me as I explain each location and give you a peek inside each restaurant, shop, and store!

In this English lesson I will help you learn words and phrases like: clothing store, nail salon, vacant, to rent, to lease, pizzeria, fast food, drive-thru, big box store, hardware store, garden centre, beer store, animal hospital, juice bar, pharmacy, and many more!

I hope you enjoyed this English lesson about shopping plazas!

‚åõ Remember:  Always watch the video three times.  Twice today with the English subtitles on, and once tomorrow with the English subtitles off.  This will reinforce the English you have learned!

title: Understand and Use Word Stress Correctly
description:
#englishwithjennifer #accentreduction #americanenglish 
Follow the journey of Nitish, a real student from India, and learn to reduce the influence of your first language in order to speak English more clearly. In this seventh lesson, we continue our work on word stress and begin to explore common patterns.

Will we get to vowel and consonant sounds as well as intonation and linking? Yes! A lot of fun pronunciation activities are coming up as well as we start to put everything together.

title: Let's Learn English! Topic: Large Tools and Equipment! üß∞üóúÔ∏èüîß (Lesson Only)
description:
In this English lesson, you‚Äôll learn the names and meanings of large tools and heavy shop equipment that you often see in garages, workshops, and on construction sites.

In this lesson you‚Äôll learn words like: shop-vac, vise, anvil, chain hoist, workbench, chop saw, jack, jack stands, bench grinder, log splitter, leaf blower, wood chipper, table saw, and many more.

As we go through the lesson, I‚Äôll give you clear and simple definitions so you know exactly what each tool is used for, and I‚Äôll share example sentences so you can practice using these words in real life. This lesson is great if you want to expand your vocabulary and talk more confidently about heavy-duty tools and equipment in English.

I hope you enjoy this free English class about large tools and equipment!

title: FADE and FIZZLE - What does it mean to FIZZLE Away?  Learn English with Mr Duncan
description:
Today's English lessons -- What does Fizzle mean? It is a fact of life that things can never stay the same. Moments of time will come and go. Feelings of happiness will appear and disappear. The existence of a certain thing will be around for a period of time... until it disappears. People will come into your life and be part of your daily existence. Something you own will be yours. And you will treasure that thing until it is no longer there. Things come and things go. This is partof life. Some thing vanish suddenly, while other things slowly disappear.

title: What is an ANTOMYN? Learn how to express opposite things in English. #mrduncanenglish
description:
What is an antonym? We are looking at using opposite words. When we talk about opposite words, we mean words that are the reverse or as the name suggests, opposite things that go the other way. So we often talk about direction, or maybe one person is going that way and the other person is going that way. We can say they are going in opposite directions. The same thing is true with English words. There are words that can go one way, and of course there are words that express the opposite meaning. We will look at some of them.

Mr Duncan has been teaching English for free on YouTube for over 18 years. Have fun learning English as a second language. Captions are available. #englishaddictwithmrduncan #mrduncanenglish #duncanenglish #misterduncan #mrduncantheenglishaddict

I created this video to help you nail the pronunciation of the word ‚Äúwater‚Äù in American English. But I also need your help with a very important task: to raise money for Team Water! That‚Äôs right, this video is for people learning about speaking English more confidently (and there‚Äôs a LOT here for you‚Ä¶50 practice sentences, to be exact!) but it‚Äôs also to help raise awareness for Team Water‚Äôs critically important global mission. Team Water‚Äìled by YouTube legends Mr. Beast and Mark Rober‚Äìis working with Water Aid to provide fresh water to 2 million(!) people worldwide. The work is taking place in some incredibly challenging places where people are in dire need of fresh water. So if you‚Äôve been working on speaking English more like a native speaker using my content I‚Äôm asking that you consider a donation to Team Water. Nothing is too small! description:

When we say something is steeped in history, we are describing a place that has a long and historical past. Everywhere you look, there is something to remind you that you are in no ordinary place. title: How Do You Stress Words in English? | Sound Natural!
description:
#englishwithjennifer #accentreduction #americanenglish 
Follow the journey of Nitish, a real student from India, and learn to reduce the influence of your first language in order to speak English more clearly. In this sixth lesson, I explain what exactly happens on a stressed word. The key is to lengthen the vowel sound. A stressed vowel sound is longer, louder, and at a high pitch.

Will we get to vowel and consonant sounds as well as intonation and linking? Yes! A lot of fun pronunciation activities are coming up as well as we start to put everything together. 

CHAPTERS
0:00 Preview
0:36 Intro
4:52 Additional practice with stressed words and stressed syllables.
5:33 Where to gain more practice with me

title: How do I describe things in English?  - English Addict with Mr Duncan #englishaddictwithmrduncan
description:
Expressing common things is what we are doing today. And I hope you are ready for that. Common. Something that is common is something that is often seen. Something that you might see often is commonly seen. Maybe if you go to a certain place at a certain time, you will see something that is common, something that is in many places, something that you might see again and again and again. So that is the most basic way of describing the word common. Something that you will see quite often. Something that you will see often and it is often seen.

Mr Duncan has been teaching English for free on YouTube for over 18 years. Have fun learning English as a second language. Captions are available. #englishaddictwithmrduncan #mrduncanenglish #duncanenglish #misterduncan #mrduncantheenglishaddict

title: Let's Learn English! Topic: Opposites! üè¨üèõÔ∏èüôÇüôÅ (Lesson Only)
description:
In this English lesson you'll be learning pairs of words that are exact opposites. Studying opposite words together is a really effective way to build your vocabulary, because remembering one word often helps you recall the other. I'll make sure to include example sentences, clear pronunciation, and simple explanations of what each word means.

In this English lesson you'll learn words such as: to argue and to agree, natural and artificial, clean and dirty, guilty and innocent, maximum and minimum, tight and loose, above and below, foolish and wise, interior and exterior, include and exclude, and many more!

I hope you find this free English lesson on opposites both helpful and enjoyable. Thanks for watching, and have an amazing day!

‚åõ Remember:  Always watch the video three times.  Twice today with the English subtitles on, and once tomorrow with the English subtitles off.  This will reinforce the English you have learned!

title: Is Speed Harming Your Pronunciation?
description:
#englishwithjennifer #accentreduction #americanenglish 
Follow the journey of Nitish, a real student from India, and learn to reduce the influence of your first language in order to speak English more clearly. In this fifth lesson, I stress the importance of not rushing when we speak. We need to remain in control of our articulation. We slow down and articulate our key words more carefully.

Will we get to vowel and consonant sounds as well as intonation and linking? Yes, attention to word stress, individual sounds, intonation and other aspects is coming up in this series, but I needed to emphasize the importance of clarity over speed. Nitish, like many other advanced students of English, tends to rush, and the fast rate of speech has negatively impacted comprehensibility. However, by slowing down just a bit, he's already improved!

CHAPTERS
0:00 Preview
0:35 Intro
1:20 Learning to slow down and articulate words more clearly
6:43 Where to gain more practice with me

Thanks to Nitish for coming on camera with me! Follow him on Instagram. @nitish.malhotraa

title: ARE YOU READY?  Be prepared and Learn English today. #englishaddictwithmrduncan
description:
Are you ready to learn English? We are looking at prepare words and phrases. So basically words and phrases connected to making plans or getting ready to prepare or to prepare a certain thing. Maybe you have to prepare yourself as well. So there are many ways of looking at the word prepare. You make preparations. You prepare to do something. When we talk about the word prepare, we are talking about a thing done in preparation for an action or situation. something that is approaching, something that will occur or of course something you are about to do.

Mr Duncan has been teaching English for free on YouTube for over 18 years. Have fun learning English as a second language. Captions are available. #englishaddictwithmrduncan #mrduncanenglish #duncanenglish #misterduncan #mrduncantheenglishaddict

title: 'Get on your Soapbox' - What does this English phrase mean?  #englishaddictwithmrduncan
description:
It's time to learn English. You may have noticed that we are now living in a time when people seem enthusiastic and very willing to express their personal opinions about things. They are eager to share their points of view on particular topics. Subjects such as politics, religion, and social issues affecting certain parts of the community are all common topics of conversation and opinion. To have an opinion can be expressed as holding a belief, having a point of view, one's feelings on a certain subject might be expressed as an opinion. It is your viewpoint as you see it.

Mr Duncan has been teaching English for free on YouTube for over 18 years. Have fun learning English as a second language. Captions are available. #englishaddictwithmrduncan #mrduncanenglish #duncanenglish #misterduncan #mrduncantheenglishaddict

title: Come, join us on our holiday to Wales üè¥Û†ÅßÛ†Å¢Û†Å∑Û†Å¨Û†Å≥Û†Åø
Learn How to Use Embedded Questions to Ask Polite English Questions ü§î‚ùìü§∑
description:
In this English lesson I will help you learn how to make questions sound more polite and natural by using embedded questions. For example, instead of directly asking ‚ÄúWhere is the bank?‚Äù, you could ask ‚ÄúDo you know where the bank is?‚Äù This feels just a bit more polite and less direct. In this English class I'll give you several examples that you can use in everyday conversations.

I'll help you learn common English questions to ask about places, people, names, and things using embedded questions. You'll learn phrases like: Do you know where my car keys are?, Do you know where the bathrooms are?,  I wonder what her name is., Do you know where my phone is?, Do you know who that is?, and many more!

Finally, I'll help you learn about other verbs you can use in embedded questions, not just ‚Äúis‚Äù or ‚Äúare.‚Äù For example: Do you know what that was?, Do you know what to do?, Do you know where we should go?, and Do you know what you want?

By the end of this lesson, you‚Äôll know some common English questions and statements that you can use in your next English conversation.

Have a great day!

‚åõ Remember:  Always watch the video three times.  Twice today with English subtitles on, and once tomorrow with the English subtitles off.  This will reinforce the English you have learned!

description:
#englishwithjennifer #accentreduction #americanenglish 
Follow the journey of Nitish, a real student from India, and learn to reduce the influence of your first language in order to speak English more clearly. In this fourth lesson, we continue to focus on hearing and counting syllables, which is essential before we work on word stress.

title: ARE YOU A FUSSY EATER? What food do you dislike? - Learn English #englishaddictwithmrduncan
description:
A person might be fussy about what they eat to be fussy about something means choosy. You are very choosy about what you like. I only eat certain types of food. I am very fussy about what I eat and people can be very fussy about the types of food they eat. They will only eat certain things. A person might only eat certain types of food. We might describe this person as a fussy eater, a person who is a fussy eater is a person who chooses very carefully the types of food they eat. I like that food, but I don't like that food. I like to eat that, but I don't like to eat that. A person can be a fussy eater. They choose the food they eat very carefully. A person might dislike a certain food because of the way it is produced or what it consists of. So there are many reasons why someone might dislike a type of food. Perhaps what it is, the way it is produced. So there might be other reasons besides taste. It is not just the flavour of the food that might be a problem, it might also be the way in which it is produced or what it is made of.

Mr Duncan has been teaching English for free on YouTube for over 18 years. Have fun learning English as a second language. Captions are available. #englishaddictwithmrduncan #mrduncanenglish #duncanenglish #misterduncan #mrduncantheenglishaddict

title: Pronunciation Listening Quiz: Rising or Falling Intonation?
description:

title: GOSSIP and RUMOUR words and phrases What does 'gossip' mean? #mrduncanenglish
description:
What is gossip? Learn English with Mr Duncan. You are probably wondering what I am talking about today. We are looking at something a habit, a habit, a human habit, something that people do. Some people like to do this particular thing. Today we are looking at the subject of spreading gossip and rumours. People like to do it. I think sometimes when people are bored, when they have nothing to do, maybe they will like they like to talk about other people. They like to gossip.

title: Learn English Small Talk for Fridays and Mondays at Work or School üë∑üíºüë®‚Äçüè´
description:
Are you ready to learn some English small talk? Small talk refers to short, light conversations we have with the people around us. In this English lesson, you‚Äôll learn useful small talk phrases for both Fridays as you leave work or school and Mondays when you return.

You'll learn common English questions you can use with coworkers, classmates, and even friends and family.  In this lesson you'll learn:

- Friday small talk phrases for leaving work or school for the weekend.
- Monday questions to ask about someone's weekend.
- How to sound friendly and natural in everyday English conversations.
- Topics like sports, the weather, the news, and weekend plans.

I hope this lesson helps you feel more confident when speaking English. I hope later this week you have a great Friday, an awesome weekend, and a wonderful Monday!

title: Learn EYE and SIGHT English idioms. What is a sight for sore eyes?  #englishaddictwithmrduncan
description:
Learn Eye idioms and sight expressions. We often forget just how amazing our senses are. The five senses we have that help us to make sense of the world around us. To sense is to connect through feeling. The five senses we have help to achieve this connection. To have sense is to understand in a clear logical way. So the word sense can be used in many different ways. Today we will look at words and phrases connected to one of those senses. learn English phrases connected to the 'eye' and 'sight'.

Mr Duncan has been teaching English for free on YouTube for over 18 years. Have fun learning English as a second language. Captions are available. #englishaddictwithmrduncan #mrduncanenglish #duncanenglish #misterduncan #mrduncantheenglishaddict

title: An English Pronunciation Lesson! Topic: Words That Almost Sound The Same - Minimal Pairs ü•§üëÆüêëüö¢
description:
In this English pronunciation lesson you will learn the meaning of over 50 English vocabulary words.  I'll also focus especially on how to pronounce them. Each word will be part of a pair and they'll differ just a little bit in how you pronounce them. In this lesson I'll say each word clearly, define it, and give lots of example sentences.

In this English lesson we'll look at the minimal pairs: shoes and choose, rink and ring, man and men, can and can't, face and phase, ankle and uncle, cheap and jeep, fan and van, ship and sheep, luck and look, bed and bad, cap and cap, cup and cop, word and world, and many more!

I hope you enjoy this English lesson about minimal pairs! Have a great day!

title: What does 'TIT for TAT' mean? - Learn ENGLISH phrases with Mr Duncan  #mrduncanenglish
description:
Tit for tat is used to refer to a situation in which an action or retaliation is equivalent to the action that is done in response to something. In other words, put simply, I do something to you. You do a similar thing in retaliation to me. Two people are fighting, arguing. They are having some sort of battle or war. So I do that. You do that, then I do that, then you do that. The things that we do to each other will be similar. They have similar consequences. Tit for tat is what we often refer to it as. To retaliate means to hit back or return the attack with a similar response. So I do something to you. You return. You retaliate by doing something back at me. To retaliate means to hit back or return the attack with a similar response. The retaliation. So when we talk about the retaliation, we are describing the situation where a response is taking place.

Mr Duncan has been teaching English for free on YouTube for over 18 years. Have fun learning English as a second language. Captions are available. #englishaddictwithmrduncan #mrduncanenglish #duncanenglish #misterduncan #mrduncantheenglishaddict

title: WHAT DOES THE WORD 'DOGMA' MEAN? - English words and phrases (vertical)  #englishaddictwithmrduncan
description:
TRANSCRIPT - Here's an interesting word that I've heard used recently by one or two political commentators. The word is dogma. Oh, Mr. Duncan, does it have anything to do with dogs? Well, I can safely say the word dogma has nothing to do with dogs whatsoever. Dogma is a noun. It is an official system of principles or tenets concerning faith, morals, behaviour and so on. For example, those of the church. So we often see dogma as maybe a set of rules or principles that are put forward by a certain group or organization. Dogma quite often something that is accepted as being part of that particular thing. Normally in the form of rules, things that have been laid down as rules. We might also say it is prescribed doctrine proclaimed as unquestionably true by a particular group. So again when we look at dogma we are talking about rules things that are put forward. Also it is something that generally is accepted by a group of people as well. A settled or established opinion, belief or principle is often referred to as dogma. Interestingly enough, interestingly enough, interestingly enough, nothing to do with dogs. Isn't that amazing? Dogmatic is the adjective form of the word. So if you are holding dogma as one's belief or direction, we can say that person is dogmatic. They will often follow rules or principles as their guide in life. And this of course can refer to many things not only religion but it can be anyone's principles any thing or their direction the direction of a person how they see themselves and the rules that bind their existence or life. So it can also exist I suppose in politics as well. You can have dogma in politics. A person can be dogmatic with their principles. And the word originates, by the way, for those wondering, the word dogma originates from Greek to mean what seems good or the way to think. So dogma itself is just way of thinking what appears to be the best way to think and that is how that particular word evolved over the years. So there it is, today's interesting word, dogma. And as I said, it has absolutely nothing nothing at all to do with dogs.

title: What a LOAD of RUBBISH! - Do we say 'trash' in British English or American English? #mrduncanenglish
description:
Mr. Duncan, can you please tell us is there a difference
between the words trash and rubbish?

Well, in fact, there are quite a few
differences between these words.

Quite often people will ask about the differences

in the uses between American English and British English,

and you would be right to do so
because there are differences.

For example, 'trash' is used in American English,

so quite often you will hear the word 'trash' used

when we talk about things that people are throwing away,

things that people don't need anymore,

things that people throw out,

the things that they don't want.

they throw out the trash.

title: Let's Learn English! Topic: What's the Difference Between...? üêäüè¢üêÅ (Lesson Only)
description:
In this English lesson you will learn the difference between some English word pairs. Do you know the difference between an apartment and a condo? What is the difference between a crocodile and an alligator? Have you seen a mouse or a rat in your apartment? Can you tell the difference between all of these things?

In this English lesson I'll help you learn about: sea and ocean, frog and toad, sensitive and sensible, democracy and monarchy, to lend and to borrow, pancake and crepe, needs and wants, to lie and to lay, ice cream an gelato, jam and jelly, and many more!

I hope you're able learn some new vocabulary words that you can use in your next English conversation!

Have a great day and don't forget to learn some English!

‚åõ Remember:  Always watch the video three times.  Twice today with English subtitles on, and once tomorrow with the English subtitles off.  This will reinforce the English you have learned!

title: Do you have INFLUENCE? - What is influence? Learn English with Mr Duncan #englishaddictwithmrduncan
description:
Influence.
I think it's a very interesting word
and also an interesting situation
that can arise quite often in life.
Influence.
You might be surprised to find out
just how often influence takes place,
and also how many people have influence as well.
It is possible for one person to have
influence or to influence another person.
So as you can already tell,
the word influence can be used
as both a noun and also a verb as well.
We can also describe a person as influential.

Mr Duncan has been teaching English for free on YouTube for over 18 years. Have fun learning English as a second language. Captions are available. #englishaddictwithmrduncan #mrduncanenglish #duncanenglish #misterduncan #mrduncantheenglishaddict

title: C1-C2 Grammar Quiz: Common Mistakes
description:
#englishwithjennifer #gramamr #c1english 
C1-C2 students must learn to avoid these kinds of mistakes. First, watch for "dangling" modifiers -- these kinds of reduced adverb clauses with a participle must have the same subject as the main clause. Second, be careful with subject-verb agreement. Finally, coordinated pairs of words (with "and"/"or") as well as lists must have parallel structure. That means all the items grouped together must be grammatically equal.

title: Is there a FLY in the OINTMENT? - Learn English phrases with Mr Duncan #englishaddictwithmrduncan
description:
You know what it's like.
There you are with your big plan to do something.
And you are 100% sure that it will
go perfectly as far as you can tell.
There is nothing that could possibly spoil your arrangement.
The thing you have planned is your goal
or something you wish to do in a certain way.
However, there is always the possibility of something going wrong.
That unexpected surprise that comes along,
or perhaps something that was there,
but you did not feel as if it would cause any problems.
There is a very interesting phrase in English
that we can use to describe something
that we did not see as causing
or creating a possible problem.
When this thing does occur
and your plans are in some way spoilt,
we can say that particular occurrence is 'a fly in the ointment'.
What does the expression 'fly in the ointment' mean?

Mr Duncan has been teaching English for free on YouTube for over 18 years. Have fun learning English as a second language. Captions are available. #englishaddictwithmrduncan #mrduncanenglish #duncanenglish #misterduncan #mrduncantheenglishaddict

title: English Collocations You Must Know for Towns and Cities!
description:
Collocations are two words that are very often seen together. In this English lesson I'll help you learn some very common English collocations that we use when talking about towns and cities. Let's go on a tour of my town and I'll help you learn as we go from place to place!

In this English lesson you'll learn words like: close-knit community, community centre, public library, residential area, commercial area, industrial area, busy street, quiet street, small town, big city, and more!

I hope you enjoy this free English class about town and city collocations, and I hope you enjoy the views along the way!

‚åõ Remember:  Always watch the video three times.  Twice today with English subtitles on, and once tomorrow with the English subtitles off.  This will reinforce the English you have learned!

title: Let's Learn English! Topic: When Things Go Wrong Part 2 üí•‚ö†Ô∏èüîß (Lesson Only)
description:
In this English lesson I will help you learn 30 common vocabulary words that we use to describe situations that aren't going well, or didn‚Äôt go well. If you're talking about a plan that failed, an event that flopped, or a misstep at work, these words will help you express yourself naturally in your next English conversation.

In this English lesson you'll learn words like: chaos, lost cause, downturn, to bungle, to botch, debacle, slip-up, screw-up, error, misstep, blunder, setback, omission, downfall, fiasco, snag, and many more.

I hope you enjoy this English lesson about when things go wrong. By the way, this is part 2! You can find part 1 right here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=feDPf7keqX8

title: THE HEAT IS ON - can you feel the heat? Learn English words to express feeling HOT #mrduncanenglish
description:
Learn English words to express feeling hot. It's a hot day here in England. Mr Duncan explains the words to describe feeling hot. The heat is on. Can you stand the heat? A hot day can be described in many ways. It's a scorching day. It's scorching hot today. It's a sweltering day.
To swelter is to feel uncomfortably hot. It's baking hot today. It's burning hot.

Mr Duncan has been teaching English for free on YouTube for over 18 years. Have fun learning English as a second language. Captions are available. #englishaddictwithmrduncan #mrduncanenglish #duncanenglish #misterduncan #mrduncantheenglishaddict

title: Learn the names of different types of chairs with Mr Duncan - English Things explained / July 2025
description:

In this lesson, we will look at the names and uses of different types of chair. Chairs come in all shapes and sizes. A chair can also be described as a seat. A thing you sit in or on, is a chair. title: An English Lesson about Starting Again
description:
In this English lesson I will help you learn 10 phrases that you can use to describe starting again. We all take breaks in life for one reason or another, but at some point we resume what we were doing.

Maybe you took a break from studying English, or stopped playing a sport because of an injury. Maybe you took some time off work.

When you return to what you were doing before, these are the common English phrases you would use.

In this English lesson you'll learn the phrases: back at it, back on track, back in the swing of things, back in the groove, pick up where you left off, ease back into it, get into a rhythm, back in action, back to business, and make a comeback.

‚åõ Remember:  Always watch the video three times.  Twice today with English subtitles on, and once tomorrow with the English subtitles off.  This will reinforce the English you have learned!

title: Are you TALKING to a BRICK WALL? - Learn English phrases with Mr Duncan  #mrduncanenglishaddict
description:
(SCRIPT) ----
There are two important things that
we all must do in our day to day lives.

The first is to be understood.

The word understood is the
past tense of understand.

The act of letting other people know
exactly what you mean is in important.

In daily life, you want to be understood.

And of course, the other people around you
need to understand what it is you are saying.

Sometimes we might try to get another
person to understand what we are saying.

We will try our best to explain
something as clearly as possible.

Of course, in this situation it is
important that the other person is listening.

You might say that most conversations
involve more than one action.

The action of expressing and listening
both take place during any type of conversation,

whether you are speaking to
one individual or a whole crowd of people,

the same rule applies.

You have to make sure your message is clear

and those around you must be listening.

To listen is to give your attention
to what is being said.

I'm sure you have been in
this situation yourself.

There you are, trying to explain
something to another person.

You are being as clear as you can
in your explanation.

However, the person you are speaking to
is not listening to what you are saying.

The other person is not paying attention.

To pay attention is to give your
whole observance to a particular thing.

You pay attention to something.

You give your full concentration
to what is happening around you.

The opposite of this is often expressed as
'not giving your full attention' or 'not paying attention'.

Someone is talking to you,
but you are not concentrating on them.

Your mind is elsewhere.

You are not giving your full attention.

There are many reasons why this might happen.

Perhaps you are distracted by something else.

Maybe you have something on your mind
and it is making it hard for you to concentrate.

Perhaps the other person is talking
about something you have no interest in.

We often view this type of behaviour
as rude and disrespectful.

There is an interesting phrase that expresses the feeling
of talking to someone who is clearly not listening to you.

You might say talking to you is
'like talking to a brick wall'.

This phrase clearly shows that you are
annoyed by the other person's behaviour.

Clearly they are not listening
to what you are saying.

You might as well be talking to a brick wall.

Perhaps someone is not taking your advice.

They are ignoring your suggestions and because of that,
they keep making the same mistakes over and over again.

You can say that your advice is 'falling on deaf ears'.

Everything you have said has been ignored.

Once again, you might also say that
'it is like talking to a brick wall'.

All of your good advice has been wasted.

The other person is not listening
to what you are saying.

"Are you even listening to what I'm saying?"

"I might as well be talking to a brick wall."
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Mr Duncan has been teaching English for free on YouTube for over 18 years. Have fun learning English as a second language. Captions are available. #englishaddictwithmrduncan #mrduncanenglish #duncanenglish #misterduncan #mrduncantheenglishaddict

title: What does TRIAL AND ERROR mean? - Learn ENGLISH phrases with MR DUNCAN  #englishaddictwithmrduncan
description:
What does 'trial and error' mean?

We often use the phrase trial and error
whilst learning or developing something.
In this sense, the word 'trial' simply means 'try'.
Each time you try, it is a type of trial.
Of course, with each trial there will be errors.
Nothing goes right the first time...

title: This is an EXCLUSIVE English Lesson - Learn with Mr Duncan  #englishaddictwithmrduncan
description:
Here is an interesting word that we often use
when we want to express how special something is.

Perhaps you are trying to sell something,

and you wish to express just
how unique that particular thing is.

Perhaps it is something that only
a certain number of people can have or obtain.

Today's interesting word is 'exclusive'.

The word 'exclusive' can be used in many ways
and in various situations.

As an adjective, the word exclusive means
excluding or not admitting other things.

By this we mean one thing has the right
or the authority to reject others.

To exclude means to push certain things aside.

You might say that excluding is a type of reject.

So in this sense, if something is exclusive,
it means only a few things will be allowed in.

A person's thinking can be exclusive,

if they are only concentrating
on one certain subject or aim,

a person might have an exclusive
focus on becoming successful.

They will push all negativity aside.

They will only concentrate
on the things that will help them.

This type of thinking is exclusive.

A certain method of learning
might be described as exclusive.

All parts of the subject are going
to be studied without any distractions.

To completely focus on something
in a direct way is exclusive.

Something that is restricted to one person,
a group, or an area concerned is exclusive.

You can have exclusive possession of something.

You are the only person that
owns that particular thing.

For example, you can have
exclusive ownership of a property.

No other person can claim ownership
of that particular property.

Something that is available to only a few select people

and quite often is considered high class
or sophisticated, might be described as 'exclusive'.

An exclusive hotel.

This hotel is exclusive.

Only certain people can afford
to stay at this place,

thus making it exclusive for the wealthy.

We can also use exclusive
to define, 'not including'.

That is to say, something has been left out.

It has not been included.

The prices of the food on
the menu are exclusive of tax.

This means that the extra tax has not been
included in the prices on the menu.

As a noun, the word exclusive means an item or story
published or broadcast by only one source.

For example, one particular newspaper has some information
and is going to publish it as an exclusive.

It is their exclusive story.

The story is an exclusive.

No one else has the information.

The newspaper has the exclusive.

It is their big story.

We often relate this word to 'exclude'
as in 'push away' or 'shut out',

which is where the word 'exclusive' originates from.

Mr Duncan has been teaching English for free on YouTube for over 18 years. Have fun learning English as a second language. Captions are available. #englishaddictwithmrduncan #mrduncanenglish #duncanenglish #misterduncan #mrduncantheenglishaddict

title: Interviewing the people of Brighton, UK ‚õ±Ô∏è
'Are you avoiding me?'  Mr Duncan talks about avoiding things - #englishaddictwithmrduncan
description:
In this English lesson Mr Duncan talks about 'avoiding' things.
Language captions are available. (From English Addict ep 374)
Watch Mr Duncan 'LIVE' every Sunday at 2pm UK time.

In life, we often find ourselves trying to avoid something.
Perhaps a chore,
something you have to do at home.
I will be honest with you.
I don't like doing chores.
There are many things
you have to do to keep yourself well and healthy and clean,
not only personally, but also around you as well.
The chores that you have to do around the house,
the things you have to do just on a daily basis.
You do something every day, or maybe you do something occasionally.
You might clean the house twice a week.
You might wash your clothes once a week.
You normally put lots and lots of washing in the washing machine.
Or maybe you have to wash the dirty dishes either by hand.
Or in the dishwasher.
The electric dishwasher.
What a wonderful invention.
But it is still a pain
because you have to put the dishes in to the dishwasher.
And to be honest with you, sometimes I try to avoid doing that,
and quite often there will be a large pile of dishes and dirty pots
waiting to go into the dishwasher.
We might also try to avoid a person as well,
someone we don't want to know.
Someone we would rather avoid them.

description:
In this English lesson I will help you learn vocabulary that you can use to talk about injuries, health care, and medicine. I'm a bit of an injury expert right now as I recently hurt myself while playing baseball. In this English lesson I'll relate my story, and I'll also help you learn some English along the way.

In this English lesson you'll learn words and phrases like: to hurt yourself, to injure yourself, to call an ambulance, emergency room, to diagnose, to treat, painkiller, ice pack, swelling, sling, crutches, wheelchair, x-ray, ct scan, and many more!

I hope you enjoy this English class about injuries!

title: MR DUNCAN explains the English phrase - 'Save it for a rainy day' What does it mean? #englishaddict
description:
SCRIPT... 

One of the most common problems that
we all find at some point in our lives

is having enough money to cover
those unexpected events.

Many people like to save money
for such an occurrence.

They might have a special
emergency fund that they keep aside

for those moments that may
come suddenly out of the blue.

To come 'out of the blue' means
to appear without warning.

Something you are not expecting
to happen comes out of the blue.

There is a lovely phrase that we use to describe
the action of putting money aside for emergencies.

We often say that we are saving
that money 'for a rainy day'.

The rainy day, of course, is the problem.

A moment of time when something
unexpected occurs.

That is the rainy day.

Perhaps an unexpected bill
arrives on your doorstep.

That money put aside will come in
very useful to pay off the debt

without having to worry too much about it.

Perhaps a serious problem occurs
with something in your house.

Maybe some emergency repairs
have to be carried out.

Once again, that money you have put aside
will help you pay for that work to be done.

The rainy day might also be your general future.

A small amount of money that you have put aside or invested
in some way will come in useful later on in your life.

We can also describe this type of saving as a nest egg.

Something put aside for that unexpected
moment that might just crop up out of the blue.

The phrase 'crop up' means appear or occur,
quite often in an unexpected way.

A problem might crop up.

Something crops up suddenly,
thus creating a problem.

That is the reason why having something put by
or saved in a safe place is a wise thing to do.

You are keeping something back 'for a rainy day'.

title: What does the English word 'inkling' mean? Learn English with Mr Duncan #englishaddictwithmrduncan
description:
Sometimes it is possible to know something just by observing or watching closely. A small detail that was observed might give away lots of clues to something. To give away is to reveal something.
It has been given away. In this sense, we are using the phrase 'give away' to mean 'show' or 'tell' someone something that would have been otherwise hidden. You might 'give away' the answer to a question. You might 'give away' a secret to someone that should not have been told. A person trying to hide something might accidentally 'give away' their secret. Today's word relates to this event occurring. The word is 'inkling'. What does 'inkling' mean?

title: Euphemisms: Are you speaking politely?
description:
#englishwithjennifer #conversation #vocabulary  #americanenglish
Learn what euphemisms are and how to use them.

There are softer, more polite ways of speaking. Euphemisms help us sound more sensitive and considerate. Learn some common expressions used in everyday English:
elderly
senior citizen
hard of hearing
visually impaired
pass away
the deceased
late husband/wife
go to the bathroom/use the restroom
slender
Avoid mentioning someone being overweight.

title: MR DUNCAN asks - Are you CAUGHT in a LIE? - Learn English phrases with Mr Duncan #mrduncanenglish
description:
NEW LESSON - Here is an interesting phrase that we often use to describe a negative situation that we have literally created for ourselves. It perfectly describes the way in which one small action can have big consequences. The consequence of something is the result or the outcome. The action is what creates the consequence. In this particular phrase, we are talking about lying. Have you ever been caught in a lie?
Mr Duncan has been teaching English for free on YouTube for over 18 years. Have fun learning English as a second language. Your own language captions are available.  #englishaddictwithmrduncan #mrduncanenglish #duncanenglish #misterduncan #mrduncantheenglishaddict

title: "For What It's Worth" - Sound Natural in Conversation!
description:
#englishwithjennifer #conversation #vocabulary  #americanenglish 
Let's how to use the phrase "for what it's worth."

Say "for what it's worth" when you're not sure if your statement or observation is going to be helpful or appreciated. This will make you sound more natural and possibly even more sensitive.

title: What is a 'CHEAT'? - To cheat or be cheated! - Learn English with Duncan #englishaddictwithmrduncan
description:
All languages consist of many different types of words, each with their own individual meaning. Some of those words have positive meanings, whilst others have negative meanings. For some reason, many people learning a language find they are more interested in the negative words rather than the positive ones. There is a strange curiosity that exists into how other languages express those darker sides of our personalities. Today's word is a common one. It is a word that can be used as both a noun and a verb. This intriguing word is a CHEAT. In general terms, the word cheat means mislead or trick someone into doing or believing something. To make a promise that will not be carried out is cheat.

Mr Duncan has been teaching English for free on YouTube for over 18 years. Have fun learning English as a second language. Captions are available. #englishaddictwithmrduncan #mrduncanenglish #duncanenglish #misterduncan #mrduncantheenglishaddict

title: What does the phrase 'ON THE SPOT' mean? - Learn English with Mr Duncan  #englishaddictwithmrduncan
description:
Here is an interesting English phrase that we often use when we find ourselves in a moment that is hard to respond to, a situation or an event that occurs in which we feel helpless and unable to answer. The phrase is on the spot. To be 'on the spot'. Means that you are in a situation or moment where you have to think quickly. Mr Duncan has been teaching English for free on YouTube for over 18 years. Have fun learning English as a second language. English Addict is also LIVE every Sunday from 2pm UK time. title: Penny Problems! - Master These U.S. Idioms & Phrasal Verbs
description:
#englishwithjennifer #vocabulary #pennies #currentissues #idioms 
Learn the fate of the U.S. penny! The best way to learn phrasal verbs is in a memorable context. Let's go over common phrasal verbs related to minting money and paying in cash. We'll also study American idioms related to the penny. Study these common expressions in natural-sounding examples. Boost your comprehension and overall fluency in English.

0:00 Introduction
1:08 phase out

2:38 cut down
2:46 shell out

5:05 Penny-related idioms and sayings
7:03 Quiz on idioms and sayings

title: The Present Perfect for Advanced Students in 8 Minutes!
description:
#englishwithjennifer #advancedgrammar #presentperfect #simplepast #verbtenses 
Let's dive into an advanced grammar lesson on the present perfect and contrast it with the simple past. We'll review how to form the present perfect and present perfect progressive. Learn when to use and when not to use the present perfect. Master English verbs and tenses. Gain helpful examples and valuable practice with a short grammar quiz. 

CHAPTERS
0:00 Introduction
0:51 Present perfect: form
1:21 Present perfect: connection between the past and present
1:43 When to use the simple past
1:52 When to use "used to" and "would"
2:08 Present perfect: for general past experiences
2:36 Present perfect: possible connection between past and future (actions likely to repeat)
3:15 Present perfect progressive: form
3:33 Overlap in usage (events still in progress)
3:59 Present perfect progressive: for evidence of an earlier action
4:48 Preference for the simple past in American English
5:26 Quiz: 8 questions

title: Let's Learn English! Topic: Describing People's Flaws! ü•äü¶•üòí
description:
Preply is a great way to find an English conversation partner. Use this link: 
https://preply.sjv.io/XmovKg to get 50% off your first lesson or use code BOB50 at checkout. In my experience Preply is a great way to take your English language learning to the next level!

In this English lesson we'll learn about people's flaws. In a previous English class I talked about virtues. Flaws are sort of the opposite. They are the negative characteristics of people. The types of things that other people find annoying or aggravating.

In this English lesson you'll learn vocabulary like: laziness, short temper, overconfidence, gossiping, perfectionism, cowardice, envy, jealousy, procrastination, neglectfulness, pessimism, greed, and many more!

I hope you enjoy this free English class about describing people's flaws. Have a great day!

‚åõ Remember:  Always watch the video three times.  Twice today with English subtitles on, and once tomorrow with the English subtitles off.  This will reinforce the English you have learned!

title: What is the difference between Peace & Piece? Learn English / Mr Duncan #englishaddictwithmrduncan
description:
What is the difference between 'peace' and 'piece'? Today I thought it would be nice to bring you to a beautiful place in which to relax and take it easy. Of course, we will still be taking a look at some words from the English language, after all that is why we are here together right now. I thought today we would look at some words that sound the same but are spelt differently. They also have very different meanings. They are also often used in well known English phrases. Whilst doing that, we will also have a chance to enjoy some of this beautiful scenery. Today we are looking at the words, peace and piece. Learn English with Mr Duncan in England. Language captions are available. Lesson 19

https://preply.sjv.io/XmovKg to get 50% off your first lesson or use code BOB50 at checkout. In my experience Preply is a great way to take your English language learning to the next level!

In this English lesson I will help you learn the name and activities of 20 outdoor places. These are places that you will recognize, as they are common around the world. After watching this video you'll be able to have better English conversations about all of these places.

In this English class I will visit: a beach, a playground, an orchard, a vineyard, a skatepark, a pier, a bandshell, a sports field, an outdoor market, a backyard, a town square, a garden, a boardwalk, and many more locations!

description:
In this English class you will learn words and phrases that were inspired by the behaviours of the animals, and by how they look. Animals have certain characteristics, and we've decided as English speakers to add words and phrases to the English language to describe people and things using these same looks or characteristics.

In this English lesson you'll learn words and phrases like: drowned rat, to let the cat out of the bag, the dog days of summer, to work like a dog, to horse around, snail mail, to squirrel away, pecking order, bear market, bull market, a fox in the henhouse, busy as a bee, to hold your horses, and many more!

title: Are You Forgetting English Words When Speaking? Try These Tips!
description:
In this English lesson I'll share 5 strategies that you can use when you forget English words when speaking. This is a common problem for people who are learning English. They know the words. They can understand the words, but when they need them during a conversation they forget them.

In this lesson I outline a couple tried and true strategies as well as three unique strategies that you can use when you find yourself in this situation.

I sure this will help you a lot in your next English practice conversation. Enjoy!

title: 14 Ways to Answer the Question, "How's it going?" - An English Lesson
description:
In this English lesson I will help you learn 14 different responses to the English question, "How's it going?". In my part of the English speaking world this is a very common greeting. In fact, it's the one I use quite a bit to greet colleagues, cashiers, customers at market, friends, etc.

In this lesson I'll teach you 14 responses in three categories: normal responses, enthusiastic responses, unenthusiastic responses, sarcastic / funny responses, and personal responses.

After this video you'll be all ready to greet someone when you have your next English conversation!

title: Let's Learn English at the Strip Mall / Shopping Plaza
description:
In this English lesson we'll go to the strip mall! In my part of the English speaking world we have what are called strip malls or shopping plazas. It is a place where all the stores are in a row with the door facing the parking lot. Come with me as I explain each location and give you a peek inside each store!

In this English lesson I will help you learn the words: hardware store, grocery store, employment centre, nail salon, discount store, chiropractor, dentist's office, bar, restaurant, and many more!

I hope you enjoyed this English lesson about strip malls!

In this English lesson I will help you learn the verbs we use to talk about things we do every day. As you go through your day, you do things, and in order to have a good English conversation about your day you need to know which verbs to use.

title: Join Me For A Live English Q&A Lesson!
description:
It's the first Saturday of the month, so it's time for a live English Q&A lesson! Q&A means Question and Answer. In this English class you'll be able to ask me any questions you want about the English language and I will do my best to answer them.

I know what it is like to learn a language. I've spent my fair share of time learning French. There is one thing I know is indispensable and that is being able to ask a teacher a question. Maybe you have a question about pronunciation. Maybe you have a question about something you read in a book or saw on a TV show. Come to the lesson and ask! I'm always happy to help people who are learning English!

I really look forward to seeing all of you at this English lesson!

This English lesson is from Saturday May 3, 2025.

‚úÖ If you have a question, please use this link to ask it: https://forms.gle/cFnxJJSjptKiwU8B8

title: Let's Learn English! Topic: Phrasal Nouns! üß≥üíæüìÑ (Lesson Only)
description:
Did you know that phrasal verbs sometimes have a noun to go with them that use the same words? Here are some examples: When someone breaks in and steals something from your car we call it a break-in. When you want to get away from work for a vacation, we call it a getaway.

In this English lesson I'll help you learn words like: ripoff, hangout, tuneup, breakdown, breakaway, buildup, handout, checkout, carryon, backup, pickup, tipoff, workaround, and many more!

I hope you enjoy this English lesson about phrasal verbs and phrasal nouns!

‚åõ Remember:  Always watch the video three times.  Twice today with English subtitles on, and once tomorrow with the English subtitles off.  This will reinforce the English you have learned!
